PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider the Federal Government's decision to have Telecom charge for the cost of ``Directory Assistance'' enquiries will greatly disadvantage, the sick elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the Government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for ``Directory Assistance'' enquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Imperial System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Isabella Plains Catholic Secondary School: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1. They are concerned that in the Tuggeranong Valley area of the A.C.T., no non-government schools have Year 11 and 12 places.
2. They want the new Catholic secondary school to be built at Isabella Plains to go to Year 12.

The petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensure that adequate resources are provided by the Government to allow Year 11 and 12 places to be provided at the Catholic secondary school at Isabella Plains in accordance with the Government's commitment to a dual system of education and greater school retention to Year 12.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Destruction of Parkland and Recreational Areas: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory shows the attention of the House:
to the erosion of City Hill for car park construction.
Your petitioners therefore request that further destruction of parkland and recreational areas within the city cease.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Fund
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
that there are individuals who have a conscientious objection to war because of their religious or general moral principles
and that the Parliament of this country has already recognised the right of such individuals not to have to participate in military service in time of war
and that all Australian taxpayers are required to contribute to military expenditure, regardless of their beliefs, through that part of their tax that is used for the Defence budget

and that while we acknowledge the right of the Government to levy taxes and to decide on the expenditure of moneys so collected we cannot accept that those with a conscientious objection to war should be forced to contribute to military expenditure
Your petitioners therefore pray

that the Federal Government will acknowledge the right of those who have a conscientious objection to war to withhold their taxes from military allocations and enable the military related proportion of their taxes to be used for peaceful purposes only

and, as we note that taxes are collected or disbursed for specific purposes (such as for Medicare), that the Commissioner of Taxation be directed that the military-related proportion of taxes collected from conscientious objectors to war be set aside in a separate fund, the Peace Tax Fund, to be used only for peaceful purposes to be determined by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this debate because, whilst it is early in the morning and we had to wait a while for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Minister seems to be quite amusing about a matter which I think is an ongoing problem and one for which he ought to be prepared to show a little more concern and responsibility. After all, on 3 November Senator Walsh said to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that it is deplorable that, after the company has met its obligations in terms of investment-indeed, in terms of quantity it has more than met its obligations under the plan-and the Government has met the obligations it accepted in 1983-

I interpolate there that we have asked the Minister, who is at the table now, what amount of taxpayers' money had been put into the industry pursuant to the Government's obligations. He has undertaken to let us know. I will go back to what Senator Walsh had to say:

the work force is actually letting the agreement down. I think that is very bad. If the people concerned are interested in keeping their jobs, they had better lift their game in comparison with what it was in the June quarter.

That is what Senator Walsh had to say in the Senate a couple of weeks ago. The Opposition has raised this matter on a number of occasions. We have had no serious response from the Minister in an area where one of Australia's most significant industries is being put at risk by the actions of a portion of the trade union movement which was a party to a plan which this Government brought down in 1983. Senator Button is very ready to take the credit for these plans. I think he ought to be a little more ready to accept some responsibility for the obvious creaks that are developing within the steel plan at the moment. In December 1983 Senator Button told us that the plan was essential to reverse the decline in the industry's fortune; that it was a new approach to industry policy in Australia; that it had been developed as a co-operative, involving undertakings from all parties-the steel unions and the Commonwealth Government as well as the steel producers-and that the success of the plan would depend upon various undertakings being adhered to.

Among the undertakings which were put forward and published by Senator Button-this was not something that was dreamed up by the Opposition-were undertakings by the trade unions to adhere to dispute settling procedures. One of the fundamental points which is accepted in the steel plan is that the co-operation of the work force is an essential element of success and is essential to achieving the high productivity which has to ensure adequate returns to an industry which is very capital intensive. As I understand it, at the moment the capital returns are somewhere around 8 per cent, which is not sufficient to justify the further investment which is required in this very important Australian industry-an industry in which Australia ought to be ahead of the world because of our extraordinarily valuable resources, our very high quality iron ore, our high quality coal, our technical competence and our capacity to meet the competition of the world, something which is pretty precious to this country and something about which I understand the Minister to be deeply concerned.

We find in the whole of the publications an acceptance that this is absolutely fundamental. In successive annual reports produced by the Steel Industry Authority we find clear warnings to the Government that the plan is not succeeding. After an initial improvement we find that there is a slackening off of co-operation. We find in the report we were debating last year the following clear warning:

If this pattern of industrial disputation continues, it does not augur well for the success of the industry over the remainder of the plan and, consequently, for the longer-term security of employment.

We get some backing and filling because the Minister shakes his fist at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd yesterday and says that it should not be saying anything publicly about this matter and should not be conducting its industrial relations in a public way. We find reported in the Press today that Mr Jerry Ellis, the BHP Slab and Plate Products General Manager, is reported as saying:
. . . Federated Ironworkers Association workers in the steel division at the Port Kembla works missed a record average of 13 days a year through sick leave.

One can imagine that a manager would be concerned about that. One can imagine that a manager would, in accordance with the advice given publicly by Senator Button yesterday and widely reported, take up that matter with the work force. Having been admonished by the Minister yesterday, BHP has put the record straight today. Mr Ellis is reported as saying:
We raised the issue with the FIA and they found that unacceptable and went on strike.

Fine. The company did precisely what the Minister trumpeted yesterday it should be doing. What happened? The raising of the issue was apparently unacceptable to the union and it went on strike. Mr Ellis is then reported as saying:

They ignored dispute settling procedures and if they continue to ignore established agreements we may well abandon the five-year steel plan and possibly cease any new investment in the Port Kembla steelworks.

The position really is that we have a significant industry problem here, and I would like to suggest in this debate that, in a sense, the problem we are seeing in the steel industry is symptomatic of a much broader problem that we have with respect to the development of competitive industry in this country, and therefore it ought to be a matter of far greater concern than it would appear to be to the Minister at the moment.

I think that the Minister would agree that if we are to have internationally competitive industries, it is not just a matter of getting the management and the work force to agree to a single quantum leap in productivity. The reality is that if Australian industry is going to compete, then we have to accept a continual chase of increased productivity on a permanent basis. In other words, one is not looking to move from a low level of productivity to some new plateau of productivity; one is looking to getting on to an escalator of continuing increases in productivity because that is what is being pursued in South America, in East Asia, in South Asia, in North America and in Europe. I am sure that the Minister is familiar with the fact that in regard to our manufacturing competitors there is not some static position but a continually improving position with continually improving productivity in those countries which are succeeding.

It seems to me that the significance of the problems at Port Kembla is that they reflect a lack of understanding in a significant sector of the work force that this steel plan was not about some one-off improvement but about a new way of doing business. The Government had the support of the Opposition in 1983 or 1984-whenever it was the Government brought down the steel plan-for the concept that, yes, there should be some continued government involvement and support and, yes, there should be a commitment from both management and the unions to a new way of doing business. In successive reports from the Steel Industry Authority, whether they be the quarterly reports or the annual reports, the Government has been getting regular warnings that there has been a breakdown in the commitment of the work force to this absolutely vital plan, particularly in Port Kembla.

After all, the Government was very ready to take the credit for the substantial improvement in industrial relations. As recently as the last few weeks we have had Government Ministers in here pointing with pride to the improvements in the level of industrial disputation and attributing that to the Government's way of doing business. In this industry they have brought before us successive reports, one of which, as I recall, showed a 600 per cent increase in industrial disputations. But we have a situation where the industrial disputation record is really very significantly bad. I will not go over all the quotes from the Steel Industrial Authority annual report of 1986-87, which is the most recent report we have before us, but it is made quite clear in that report that there has been a very great increase in the number of man hours lost at Port Kembla. It is 84 per cent higher than in the six months to November 1981, which was the previous worst period for industrial disputes.

Senator Button has a charming way of washing his hands of responsibility in this matter, but he has an equally charming way of accepting the credit for things when they are going well. I say to the Minister that, quite clearly, an essential part of the plan for which he is responsible has broken down and has been crumbling away now for a period of years. It simply is not good enough for him to come in here and to blame other factors, whether it is the management or the technical factors, because the report itself deals with that. On page 3 the report states:

While recognising the significance of capital investment to the long-term viability of the domestic steel industry, it is the management of the industry's labour resources that is of greatest immediate concern to the Authority.

It would appear from Senator Button's statement yesterday that he believes that the management is not living up to its part. The Opposition would agree that the management has a significant role to play in ensuring the effective use of the work force. Perhaps Senator Button will clarify in this debate whether he is saying that the management of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is fundamentally why we have got this enormous rise in industrial disputation at Port Kembla. Is he saying that this is fundamentally a management problem and not a trade union problem? It is my understanding that that is not the case. It is my understanding that what we have is a cell, a leadership group, within the ironworkers in Port Kembla who are utterly destructive in the attitudes they bring to bear on this essential industry. They are sufficiently capable leaders to be able to carry the bulk of the work force with them in this rise in industrial disputation. I understand there is a very significant problem in the work force itself.

If that is the case, does the Government say, `Well, let the market forces sort it out. If the steel industry is not competitive and we can get only an 8 per cent or a 2 per cent return, or whatever, market forces will dictate that there will be no fresh investment and eventually our steel industry will fall behind and it will cease to operate'? I must say that the Government seems very confused on this matter. Does the Government say that the steel industry plan represents something which has a government commitment and which can be made to work and in which the Government has a role and an influence which are effective? I think we should try to get some clarity into this debate in the course of dealing with these estimates.

The present situation cannot be described as even vaguely satisfactory. It is quite clear that there is a major industrial relations problem. We have had Minister after Minister and back- bencher after backbencher saying in this place that this Government knows how to handle industrial relations, and a continual reference to the fact that things are so good because of this Government's excellent management of these matters.

Here is a vital area of fundamental importance to Australia where, because of a failure in industrial relations, we have had to import more at a time when our balance of payments are at a critically difficult level, where we have seen a loss of some of that vital import replacement, where we have seen a loss of exports and where we have seen, after a growth in productivity, a decline in productivity. The Minister tells us that we have had a bit of a rise again, but the sad fact is that we also have a resurgence of industrial relations problems. We know that, if the steel industry is to continue to improve, to become more competitive and to be a jewel in Australia's economic crown, there will have to be further structural adjustments in that industry.

Australia is no different from the rest of the world. There will be a further reduction in the blue collar work force and a big increase in productivity per person employed because that is the only way that we can succeed. It seems to me that the Minister is washing his hands of responsibility in this matter. I believe that that is simply not good enough. I think we should get much clearer statements from him about the Government's analysis of who is to blame in the present circumstances and what, if anything, can be done to reverse the significant problems which are occurring in this vital Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several aspects of this matter concern me-but what has particularly concerned me is the Minister's approach to it. We heard him again this morning denigrating suggestions by the Opposition that this was not something that suddenly emerged this year; that it was something that we were warned about in the report of the Steel Industry Authority last year. Last night I asked him why a particularly significant table which showed the man hours lost through industrial disputes per employee and per centre had been omitted from this year's report of the Steel Industry Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button was trying to pretend to this chamber and to the nation that everything was right with the steel industry last year and that the problems emerged only this year. Of course, this is utter bunkum and the Minister knows it. The table produced in the 1985-86 annual report showed that at Port Kembla industrial disputes meant a loss of man hours per employee of 10.9, which was a 211 per cent increase over the previous year. I know that a 211 per cent increase does not bother Senator Button and that, according to his statement this morning, it does not exist. That rate was for the six months to June 1986. In the six months to June this year that rate has been multiplied almost by three. Let us recognise that at Port Kembla in the period to June 1986 that 10.9 man hours lost through industrial disputes per employee was about four times the average for metal products, machinery and equipment manufacturers in Australia.

We do not have the table this year-it has magically disappeared. I wonder what sort of pressure was brought to bear on the Authority by the unions to ensure that that sort of table did not appear. I look forward to hearing the Minister's response to my request last night for an explanation from the Steel Industry Authority as to why that table does not appear. But the fact is that, if the average was four times as bad at Port Kembla as it was for the metal products, machinery and equipment manufacturers in a year when Senator Button said that industrial relations were perfect and the steel plan was going well, what would it be like now? As the annual report for that year states, it is clearly evident that the number of man hours lost through industrial disputes per employee has increased significantly over the life of the steel industry plan. That seems to be absolutely intolerable. But it is equally intolerable for this Minister to pretend that, until this year, everything was wonderful. We see what has happened this year. A report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 May 1987 refers to the remarks of the General Manager of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd Steel Slab and Plate Products Division, Mr Jerry Ellis. It states:
Mr Ellis said the company had lost between $20 and $30 million because of the campaign and that it expected more losses because several clients were planning to sue it for failure to meet contracts.
He went on:
It will take at least a year or two to re-establish the confidence of our customers.

That was the situation then. Have things improved now? On the surface there has been an improvement in industrial relations. But the reality is that the union movement in Port Kembla is now threatening BHP with industrial unrest over BHP's decision to reduce its work force by a further 2,600 people to make that industry competitive and capable of surviving in the real world.

This threat of further industrial action is not fanciful; it is real. The intriguing thing is that BHP's decision to reduce its work force to 10,000 people would and does fit within the guidelines of the steel industry plan. There is no scope within that plan for union objections and claims that the employer has done something improper or something which was not envisaged in the steel industry plan. That steel industry plan, of course, aims at a level of productivity and BHP cannot achieve that level of productivity per employee with its current work force at a level of 12,600.

The big question is whether this industry is to survive. Surely the jobs of the 10,000 people who would remain in that industry are far more important - they certainly are to the whole Illawarra community and Australia - than whether 2,600 people will lose their jobs, not necessarily by sacking. I understand that the plan is simply the normal one that BHP has used of early retirements, not replacing people, in general, who leave and encouraging people to leave before their retirement age.

The reality is that this industry is at risk and there is a risk of continuing industrial unrest over this major concern. Senator Button just has to read the local newspapers in the Illawarra region to find whether there is any kind of union threat about industrial action if BHP continues with its plan to become economic, to enable it to survive. Of course that threat is there. But apart from that there have been continuing, nonsensical strikes. I read from today's Illawarra Mercury which, by the way, has an editorial called `Avoid this path to ruin', which I may refer to later in this debate. The Illawarra Mercury today reveals what is behind BHP's latest and immediate concern and why it has had to threaten that it may be forced to walk away from Port Kembla's steelworks if this pattern of industrial unrest continues. The paper reports:

BHP lost patience with its Port Kembla steel-works labour force this week because a sudden stoppage by 40 ironworkers at the Number 5 blast furnace crippled steelmaking for 48 hours and cost the company $2 million.
That is total ratbaggery at a time of crisis in the steel industry. The newspaper continues:

It was the blast furnace stoppage and less disruptive ones in the past two weeks at the coke ovens and shipping department which prompted BHP Steel's Slab and Plate Products general manager Jerry Ellis yesterday to warn that unless industrial relations improved investment at the plant would cease and it would slowly wither.

Mr Ellis cited the blast furnace stoppage as an indication some key ironworkers intended ignoring the dispute settling procedure agreed on between the company and unions four times-in the 38-hour week agreement, the Steel Industry Plan, an improved superannuation agreement and more recently after withdrawal of deregistration proceedings against the FIA and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union.

On four occasions the union pledged itself to adopt and accept appropriate settlement arrangements. The dispute settling procedures were agreed upon. Yet multimillion dollar devastations have been imposed upon the industry by unions which have refused to meet the arrangements. At the Press conference yesterday Mr Ellis said:

It is the FIA's duty to its members and the community to enable the dispute settling procedure to be followed. If it is not, then it will be an indication the FIA has abandoned the steel industry plan and we may well seek to follow suit. This would involve halting investment in the plant. As a result the plant would become uncompetitive, lose markets and gradually cease operations.

Mr Ellis explained in Wollongong yesterday that BHP Steel Chief Executive, John Prescott, had this level of strikes in mind when he spoke in Canberra this week of not being averse to recommending to the BHP Board that it walk away from Port Kembla.

Today in Wollongong-Port Kembla steel unions will be meeting to discuss both Mr Prescott's and Mr Ellis's comments. I hope that at those meetings they recognise the threat that their actions have caused to the continued existence of this industry. I find it extraordinary, as does Senator Lewis, that in this environment, the unions having given commitments on four occasions and industrial unrest having occurred not simply since the beginning of this year but also last year-and there is a threat of more to come-this Minister walks away, saying, firstly, that he has no role and, secondly, that the company is somehow to be criticised for daring to make this matter public. Senator Button's contribution to this situation as a senior Minister of this Government has been appalling. He has not sought to bring his, what should be considerable, authority to this matter. The Government has put $100m of taxpayers' funds by way of bounty into the steel industry plan, the company has put $800m of shareholders' funds into the plan and the unions have put in their contribution-non-stop industrial unrest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button, in his flippant response to my opening remarks in this debate, accused me of getting excited about the industrial relations problems made clear by the annual report of the Steel Industry Authority to 30 June 1987. If Senator Button is not excited, annoyed and disturbed by the nature of the report he ought to give this game away. I have raised the matter on previous occasions, during debate on a matter of public importance and in a number of questions. I have indicated to the Government my concern about what is happening to the steel industry. For the six months ending 30 June 1987 productivity was less than it was when the steel plan was first introduced. It was down to 239 tonnes per person per annum. In comparison with our competitors overseas it is a ridiculous figure. We understand that in the United States at the moment a figure of 800 tonnes per person per annum is being achieved. If Senator Button is not disturbed by those figures then, frankly, I do not know what will disturb him. But that was not the point that I was trying to get at. That has been adequately dealt with by my colleagues Senator Chaney and Senator Baume and, I believe, adequately dealt with by me on previous occasions. My concern is what is happening now with the steel industry at Port Kembla. My criticism is of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go right back to the very beginning. I say to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that when he organised the steel plan he organised it in a way whereby it was bound to fail because the parties to the agreement were Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The ACTU was acting on behalf of the unions. Let me quote from something which Mr Duffy said on 30 November 1983 in the other place when he was the Acting Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. He said:

The unions' undertakings are in the areas of wages, productivity, improvements and dispute settlements. They are contained in an agreement between BHP and the Australian Council of Trade Unions acting on behalf of the steel unions.
He went on to say:
Agreement has also been reached to adhere strictly to the established grievance settlement procedures and for consultation to be held on changing work modes.

That is a typical example of one of the things we have been criticising this Government for: big government, big business and big unions. This Government believes that that is the way in which to solve the nation's problems. Here is a perfect example of why it has not been the way in which to solve the nation's problems, because the truth of the matter is that the ACTU cannot deliver on behalf of the unions. The Government has delivered: it is spending the taxpayers' funds. BHP has delivered: it has invested, I think, $1.4 billion in the industry. But the ACTU cannot deliver. I would have thought that a member of the Australian Labor Party would understand that within the union movement power rises from the shop floor. It cannot be imposed from above. For the Government to think that it can enter into an arrangement with Mr Crean and Mr Kelty which will bind the union at the level of the shop floor at Port Kembla is an absolute nonsense. The Government should have realised that, if it was going to persuade BHP to invest this money in the steel industry and if it was going to spend the taxpayers' funds on this investment, then it needed to lock in the unions at the shop floor level, not up with Mr Crean and Mr Kelty, who can get into Mr Hawke's office and say all sorts of things but cannot deliver.

That is my first and most important criticism of the Government on this steel plan. As I said before, my concern is the current crisis. At the moment, BHP has indicated that it must reduce the size of its work force very substantially, back to about 10,000 employees. I might say that so long as it is done on a voluntary and retirement basis then it is in accordance with the plan which the Minister arranged. Voluntary reductions are acceptable. At the shop floor level, the Port Kembla branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia is simply not prepared to accept those reductions. That is the crisis. That is what has to be resolved. What the Minister is saying is that he is not prepared to do anything about it. That is the point I am making. I understand the concern which we all must have about the productivity for the first six months of this year. But that is not the point I am making. I am talking about the current crisis.

Let me say something additional about that current crisis. There is a major conflict within this Government about that crisis. Treasurer Keating went down to Port Kembla recently and big-noted himself down there with Mr Holmes a Court and others. He got himself national publicity and national headlines saying all sorts of things. Among the things he said was that he thoroughly agreed that BHP must prune its work force. I think that is probably a reasonable thing for the Treasurer to have said when looking at an industry facing the possibility of falling in a great heap-leaving us no industry. But what happens in the Government is that another Minister is totally opposed to that proposal. The Minister attempted to get publicity for himself and to big-note himself on the basis of being opposed to this proposal. I refer to the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West. Apparently Minister West has written to Senator Button, saying in effect that BHP should be required to maintain its work force at 12,250. Not only did Minister West want that but he wanted BHP to invest another $165m in the industry. I want to know what the Government's attitude is. Does it support Mr Keating, or does it support Mr West? I ask the Minister to tell us the truth of the matter.

What does the Government intend with regard to this crisis? Does it support a reduction of the work force? Will it try to hold BHP to maintaining a work force of 12,250, as Mr West wants? Will it require, or try to persuade, BHP to invest another $165m at Port Kembla-after BHP has already invested $1.4 billion there? They are the crucial issues which I am putting to the Minister. I cannot put them more forcefully than that. As I said, I acknowledge the problems up to 30 June of this year. But that is not the point that I am raising. What I want to know is: What is the Government going to do about the current conflict? Will we see another half-yearly report at the end of December of this year telling us that productivity has fallen even more? What the Opposition is interested in is productivity improvements in this nation. This nation is in crisis. It is facing a harsh economic climate in which our overseas competitors, our falling dollar value and our overseas debts will make us face up to reality. We want to know what this Government will do about this industry, which is crucial to this nation. Or will it allow this industry to collapse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks on this subject also. In doing so I start not in Port Kembla, where most of the attention has been directed because of events there, particularly in recent days, but actually in Newcastle, which, of course, is where our steel industry, particularly until a few years ago, was thought to have its chief home. That, of course, has changed with change in technology and other things, to some of which I hope to refer.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at Newcastle and its relationship with the steel industry. We have seen in Newcastle in the last few years a major decline in the relevance and role of the steel industry. It is, of course, still a major industry in Newcastle, but it is nothing like the industry that it was some years ago. The reasons for that are very clear and very straightforward. They have to do with the baleful influence upon that industry of the exercise of trade union power. That is the subject to which we ought to return time and again in this discussion. We should ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) what his Government proposes to do about that problem which underlies this whole debate. The ruthless, careless, shortsighted and, in many cases, totally unfeeling exercise of trade union power in the steel industry in Newcastle began the rot in the steel industry in that very fine city some years ago.

While we are on the subject of Newcastle and the exercise of trade union power, we might also look at the fate of the Newcastle State Dockyard, which at one time was one of the few dockyards in this country capable of handling large vessels, a dockyard which basically no longer exists. This is not only my opinion; it is also the opinion of Mr Norman Oakes, a former Under-Secretary or Comptroller of Accounts in New South Wales, who was appointed by the Government of New South Wales to report on the Newcastle State Dockyard. On the basis of his report, the present New South Wales Government finally faced the realities brought about by the exercise of trade union power in that area and closed the dockyard.

We also saw some years ago the total disruption of the export coal industry at the port of Newcastle by the continuing disruption of the Newcastle coal loader operations. Week after week, month after month, the operations of companies in that city-trying to go about their proper business, trying to provide employment, trying to make a profit for their shareholders-were totally disrupted by the actions of trade union officials who were operating in such a way as to put their own members out of jobs. The coal loader, finally, by agreement with the New South Wales Government, had to be taken over by private enterprise before it could hope to begin to operate half sensibly-although it has certainly not been free of industrial disruption even since that time, as anybody who can remember the Wran navy stacked up outside Newcastle will vividly recall.

Let us look at the result for Newcastle, which was once one of the most flourishing cities in Australia. I will not say that it has become a depressed area; that would not be true. Certainly, what one might call the spirit of Newcastle has been very much depressed by these events. It is no longer the optimistic city that it once was.

A very similar process is going on in Port Kembla. There is a small body of trade union saboteurs-and I use that word advisedly-who are, indeed, saboteurs of their own trade union, which, in this case, is the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, a small body of extreme left wing ideologues who do not care for the future of their industry, their city and their own trade union, but who care only for the exercise of their own power for their own ideological ends. This is going on now in Port Kembla just as, in the past, similar things went on in Newcastle.

The situation is similar to that which occurred five or six years ago in the Yallourn Valley in Victoria, when the trade unions were in charge. The then Victorian Government attempted to construct the Loy Yang power station, but by the time the project had been completed, its cost had risen to about 2 1/2 times that of the original estimate. Of course, the citizens of Victoria are paying, and for decades to come will continue to pay, the increased prices of power which that greatly increased cost of construction has loaded upon power production costs in Victoria.

Let us turn to the steel plan. It is a plan which in the past Senator Button has been very pleased to take credit for. In the first couple of years of this plan, when productivity in the steel industry was rising-not dramatically, but it was rising, and certainly from very low levels-we found Senator Button very pleased to issue Press releases, to be photographed in the company of members of the board of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), and generally to put himself forward as having been partly responsible for bringing about this rejuvenation or renaissance of the Australian steel industry. The truth of the matter is that that is all behind us. As other speakers have pointed out, the experience of the past 18 months-not the past 18 days-has been to cast a total pall over what were thought initally to be optimistic developments in this industry. In recent days, particularly, we do not find Senator Button coming forward to take the blame. It is very much a one-handed operation on the Minister's part. He has his hand out to take the credit but he has his hand behind his back when the blame is being handed out.

The truth is that the steel plan has not merely become a disaster. The truth is that it always has been a disaster. Why do I say that? I say it for two reasons at least. Firstly, even if all had gone according to plan, even if there had been none of this disruption of the so-called plan by these militant trade union bosses in Port Kembla and elsewhere, the outcome would still not have been good enough. As Senator Lewis and other speakers have pointed out, even the initial projections of the plan for productivity increases to be attained would still have left BHP's productivity performance well behind that of its international competitors-even at the time the plan was formed, without any allowance being made for the continuing productivity increases going on in the rest of the world while the plan was in operation.

The genesis of the plan seemed to be predicated on the belief that, while we were increasing our productivity, everyone else would be standing still. As Senator Button knows perfectly well-I know he does know this-of course, productivity has not been standing still in Korea or Taiwan-or even in Japan, which some people point to these days as having almost a mature steel industry, unlike, say, the steel industries in the newly emerging industrialising countries.

A second reason why the steel industry plan has been a disaster is that it has been part of the whole process adopted by this Government from the time it first took office of not telling Australians the truth, of misleading Australians about the increasingly serious state of our economy. It has been part of the whole process of conning the Australian people, in this instance into believing that under this Government we could rely upon the trade union movement to act sensibly, to act co-operatively and to act in a manner which would assist the management of the economy. That has all been part of the myth of the accord.

I have said many times that the greatest error that this Government has made throughout its whole term in office has been in its failure to tell the Australian people the truth about the serious situation of this country. The Government has told a good many untruths about the terrible situation it inherited and all that stuff, which we have grown sick of hearing in this place. But it has failed to bring home to the Australian people the seriousness of the situation with which they are faced. As a consequence, statements such as that made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a rare moment of truthfulness in May last year to the effect that we are confronting a banana republic situation come as a great shock to the Australian people. The reason that statement came as a great shock was that they had in no way been prepared for the truth.

Recently BHP began to talk seriously of abandoning the steel industry, and that has certainly come as a great shock to the Australian people; I am quite sure of that. One reason it has come as a great shock to the Australian people is that this Government, instead of seeking to bring home to the Australian people the seriousness of the situation confronting us in that industry, as in others, has thrown a great smokescreen over the industry by its continual rabbiting on about the great virtues of the steel industry plan.

The truth is that the steel industry plan is, and always has been, so much industry policy junk. A week or two ago the Industries Assistance Commission, which previously had been muzzled by being under the strong influence of Senator Button and his departmental head, Dr David Charles, but which has now been let off the leash by being moved into the Treasurer's portfolio, produced an excellent annual report, the first for years, in which, among other things, it took the stick in a big way to all of this nonsense about industry policy which this Government has been going on with for so long now.

The Commission has rightly condemned the nonsense that passes for industry policy in this country. It has pointed out that there is no such thing as a free lunch in this or any other area of economic policy and that, to the extent that this Government continues to hand out favours to particular bodies and industries which are so ill advised as to allow themselves to come under its sway, somebody else is paying. In most cases that somebody else is the Australian public. The Industries Assistance Commission has pointed out that junk similar to the steel industry plan is to be found littering the Minister's portfolio in areas such as the motor vehicle industry plan junk, the footwear, clothing and textiles plan junk, the heavy engineering manufacturing plan junk and, not least, what I have just been talking about, the steel industry plan junk.

What does the Minister propose to do about the situation that he now has on his hands regarding BHP? The answer is that he proposes to blame BHP. I suggest that he will not get away with it, but I hope that in his reply to other speakers and me in this debate he will address himself to that issue rather than merely fall back into the kinds of flippancies with which he laced his remarks earlier this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last six months Port Kembla steelworks contributed 90 per cent of the man hours lost through industrial disputes within Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) but produced about only half the steel. Clearly something special is wrong at Port Kembla. While I noted what Senator Stone said about Newcastle, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia (FIA) in general, particularly its national leadership, is a responsible and sensible union which, I believe, acts within the framework of the arrangements it makes and is honourable in its dealings with government and employers. However, the Port Kembla branch is disruptive, is disloyal to its leadership and is a left wing element of what is normally a basically sensible union. That is why one must distinguish what has been going on in Port Kembla, where half the steel is made but where 90 per cent of industrial disputes and 90 per cent of days lost occur, from what has been going on with the rest of the union.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senators Button and Walsh and Mr Keating have indicated-two of them have said it in this place-that reducing the work force at Port Kembla to 10,000 and increasing productivity to 350 tonnes per year per man is within the guidelines, within the framework of the steel industry plan and that there is nothing objectionable about it. As the survival of the steel industry depends on the plan, surely it is a matter of immense moment. If that is the Government's view, I would like the Minister to give a response to an allegation by the left wing Wollongong Branch Secretary of the FIA, Mr Nando Lelli, who has claimed that BHP had given an undertaking that it would maintain a Port Kembla work force of 12,250 to May 1988 and beyond the life of the steel industry plan. I ask the Minister whether that is a fact. If it is a fact, did the Minister regard it as of no consequence when he said that it was within the steel industry plan that the number should be reduced to 10,000? If it is not a fact, will the Minister make a clear and unequivocal statement to the union that it should stop spreading around this kind of nonsense, if it is nonsense? That is what the dispute is now centring on in the Illawarra region, the dispute that the Minister likes to pretend ended a long time ago, saying that there are no problems, that everything has improved and that everything is wonderful. As I said earlier, this is the problem at Port Kembla. It is reported in the Illawarra Mercury today that Mr Lelli said that the company:
complains now about us not meeting certain requirements but it cannot expect us to co-operate in a program to implement what it says must happen to the workforce.

Here we have a clear threat from Mr Lelli. He said, `It cannot expect us to co-operate'. That presumably means that the company cannot expect union members to work, to abide by the agreements about dispute settling procedures. The Minister is faced with a clear challenge by the FIA Wollongong Branch Secretary, Mr Lelli, because there is a clear threat that the union will not co-operate. We saw that lack of co-operation last weekend at a cost to BHP in an industrial disputation of $2m to $3m. The report went on to say:
Port Kembla FIA intended honouring its dispute settling agreement with BHP-
that is a quaint expression; I think it is honoured more in the breach than in the observance-
but-
and there is always a big `but' in these situations-
the company had created pressure on employees throughout the works by insisting on a new formula covering absenteeism, again without consulting the shop floor.
That is the claim by Mr Lelli relating to recent stoppages. He said:
This led to the stoppage at the blast furnace this week.

What we want is a clear indication from the Government about whether it is on the side of industrial responsibility, of sticking by agreements, or whether it is prepared, as the Minister has done in the last couple of days, to somehow try to claim that the blame is with BHP. It is interesting to note what those whom one could call fairly independent commentators are saying on this issue in Wollongong. Last night, as an example, the Dean of Commerce at the University of Wollongong, John Steinke, said:
. . . unless there is a change of attitude by the FIA leadership I doubt we will ever see another large investment in the steelworks.

Just to give an indication of the way that the unions have behaved and the reasons why BHP has had to do what Senator Button has said is wrong-that is to deal with this in the media-I will show the problems that BHP has had in the past. It put an advertisement in the newspapers with a message to all employees over the workers compensation dispute back in May. I will not read all of the advertisement, but in part it said this:
Yesterday . . . a group of mechanical maintenance employees at our Coal Washery went on strike over the workers' compensation issue.
In doing so, they-
defied an order of the Industrial Commission requiring an end to the campaign of strike action; and
in the case of members of the Federated Ironworkers' Association (FIA), ignored a direction of the State Council of the FIA to end the strikes.

Here we have a situation not only of dispute settling agreements being ignored, but of the defying of the Industrial Commission, that is the New South Wales body, and the union's executive. The advertisement continues:
At the time they went on strike, plant was down for maintenance and the action was deliberately calculated to maximise the impact on our operations.

So, when Senator Stone uses the word `sabotage' he is absolutely accurate. These are acts of sabotage aimed at damaging the industry on which this region depends, on which Australia's ba-lance of payments in large part depends, both for exports and import replacement, and on which all those ancillary industries in the Wollongong region, which the ironworkers themselves say involve about 30,000 employees, depend. Therefore, the economy of the whole region depends on this industry. The advertisement continues:
In recent days, the Company has said that it would not accept these rolling sectional strikes and foreshadowed action against employees who participated.

The Company did not take action at an earlier time as it was allowing the opportunity for the unions to consider their position. Following delegates' meetings last Friday, May 22, 1987, the Company was told that the campaign would continue.
In these circumstances, the Company had no alternative but to take action.

The Company had hoped that we would not reach this situation. However, the strikes have continued and the Company cannot tolerate the on-going disruption to our operations and the supply of steel to our customers.

What is happening now is that that situation in May is clearly in the minds of both management and the employers, and should be in the minds of the Minister-I said minds because he is clearly schizophrenic on this matter. The reality is that we are facing a prospect of severe industrial turmoil over a measure that the company needs to carry out in order to survive, and that is the reduction of the work force to 10,000. The Illawarra Mercury today underlined the seriousness of the situation in its editorial. It said:
Now we are careering down the road towards another confrontation which, if it occurs, will wreck the steel industry.

I draw that to the attention of the Minister because he seems to think that everything is all right. He says that all this is in the past. It is not. We are facing this problem now-the rest of Australia is facing it, even if he is not. It is about time that he joined us in recognising the problem. The editorial went on:

There seems to be a feeling around that BHP is bluffing, that it would never pull out of Port Kembla and the billions of dollars it has invested in its steel operations here. But the Slab and Plate Products general manager Jerry Ellis affirmed yesterday he was speaking for senior Steel Division management and the BHP Board in declaring investment at Port Kembla would cease unless industrial relations improved.
If that happened, the plant would wither and die.

This is the threat that we face. The Government must face up to this threat, which is underlined in a report this morning of what Mr Prescott, the Chief Executive of BHP's Steel International Group said. He is quoted as saying:
So far as Port Kembla is concerned, that threat is in the form of its industrial relations record and we aren't prepared to make further investments there until we had overcome the problems . . .
The report continues:
He said the future viability and growth potential of Port Kembla was heavily tied to exports and reliable delivery was critical for this.

So I ask the Minister the question that seems to be central to this debate: Are the unions telling the truth when they say that BHP gave an undertaking that it would maintain the Port Kembla work force at 12,250? Is the Minister aware of any such undertaking, and I ask him once again whether the reduction of the work force to 10,000 in order to make BHP viable and to provide a 350 tonnes per annum productivity level-if everyone went to work, of course-is really within the framework of the steel industry plan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall comment first of all on some of the things Senator Michael Baume has said. It is all very well for him to quote an academic from the University of Wollongong. I agree totally with what the honourable senator said. He is very good at quoting from the Illawarra Mercury, and I am just getting a copy of a May issue in which I said precisely the same things, but in much stronger language. I said precisely the same things not only about the steel industry but also about the whole city of Wollongong. Investment in Wollongong will not take place with this sort of industrial disputation problem going on as it has been. I said that in May. So Senator Baume should not come in here today venting points raised in today's Illawarra Mercury; all those things are on record. I do not disagree with them.
—You are saying things have improved.

—No, I am not saying things have improved. I will come to the issues in a minute. Several speakers have taken up a couple of points as a regular theme. For example, it was said quite bluntly by Senator Stone that I am seeking to blame the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) for what has taken place recently. That is a total misreading of what I said.
—We were just responding to your answer.

—The honourable senator should not be too smart; let me tell him what I said. I said yesterday-and he can check the Hansard record if he wants to-that I did not think it was very good industrial relations practice to announce things in the newspapers. Only six weeks ago BHP announced in the newspaper its intention to reduce the work force at Port Kembla. Subsequently BHP has said it had really made a mistake about that, perhaps it should have done it in another way. Yesterday it was reported in the papers that Mr Prescott had come up here and told the Government that BHP would withdraw from steel making in Port Kembla if the industrial disputation situation did not improve. That is not true, as I said yesterday. He did not tell the Government that. In this morning's newspaper Mr Prescott is reported as having said that he had some conversation with somebody in a passage. That is not quite the same thing as telling the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I just happen to believe, irrespective of what other people think, that these problems are very serious and it is best to confront them in the work place. I can show BHP companies in this country that four years ago had industrial relations situations as bad as those being experienced at Port Kembla by BHP now, and they have completely changed all that by their capacity and effort to communicate with the work force. Clearly there has been a breakdown in those sorts of arrangements. Senator Baume asks me whether I am aware of what Mr Nando Lelli said in the Illawarra Mercury on such and such a date, and who said what to Mr Lelli. I have no idea at all. If one were to rely on the scuttle-butt that appears in newspapers about who said what to whom, we would not get very far. But those things are really at the margin of the major issues in this matter. On Friday, 28 May, in the Illawarra Mercury, I said:

I am not particularly interested in the views of Mr Paul Matters. Currently I suppose he sees himself as being launched by this level of industrial disputation into a place of prominence in this country which he does not deserve and in my view he will not maintain.

In the same newspaper I went on to point out that the situation was disastrous for investment in Wollongong and for the prospects for the whole town. While I am not seeking to blame BHP, I do not absolve both parties from blame in this matter. Inevitably, there are faults on both sides in the way these things are handled.

I think I should point out to Opposition senators one or two other factual issues. The level of productivity increase in the steel industry in the last year or so has not been satisfactory at all. It is wrong of Senator Lewis to say that productivity in the steel industry is even now, with all of the troubles, back to what it was at the time the steel plan was put in place. At that time it was 185 tonnes or 190 tonnes per man. According to Senator Lewis, it is now 239 tonnes per man.

It is not correct to say that integrated steel mills throughout the world have attained levels of productivity of 800 tonnes per man. That is bunkum. That is true of mini-mills; it is not true of integrated steel mills anywhere. I am not seeking to retreat from the point that the productivity is not all that it ought to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the productivity in real terms in Korea?

—Probably about 400 tonnes. But the level of productivity varies greatly. I think the productivity in the United States integrated steel industry has not been really good at all. The figures that Senator Lewis is talking about relate to United States mini-mills, not integrated steel mills. The other matter of fact in Senator Lewis's remarks-perhaps this was said by Senator Baume-which I would correct is that investment by BHP has been considerably more than he said.
—I said $1.4 billion.

—Yes, Senator Baume said $800m. I would like to turn to one or two of the more important issues. First of all, I agree with Senator Chaney when he says that productivity has to be continually on the agenda, that a continual escalation in productivity is being attained in other countries and has to be sought and attained here. I do not have any problem with that as a proposition. Secondly, I do not have any problem with the view that, in order to attain those levels of productivity over time, BHP will be concerned to reduce the work force. That was inherent in the beginnings of the steel plan and it is still quite apparent that this will have to happen. The steel plan addressed the issue of how that will be done, not whether it should be done or not. The issue that was addressed was how it should be done. I think one or two Opposition spokesmen have made that point. I have no knowledge of any undertakings given by BHP, apart from those facts. It was accepted that there would be a reduction in the work force over time and that that should be achieved in certain ways. In fact, the total reduction in the work force of the steel industry in Australia has been of the order of 17,000 jobs since 1982-82. That has been accomplished in part by a process of attrition and voluntary retirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say something about the question of whether there is an industrial problem at the moment which has to be addressed. I am quite correct in saying that Senator Lewis in his earlier speeches spent most of his time talking about the industrial relations problems revealed in the steel industry report. Subsequently, I think in his fourth speech, he got on to the issue of what he described as a current industrial relations problem. Senator Baume has also talked about this matter. By the way, it is quite wrong for Senator Chaney to come in here and say that BHP has attempted to resolve the industrial relations issues-I understand that he was referring to a current dispute over absenteeism-at the workface and not in the newspapers. That is not the issue; it is whether these matters are best dealt with on site or, as I say, by slanging matches in newspapers.

Throughout the discussion there has been much by way of rhetorical question about what the Government proposes to do about the situation as it now exists. I said in earlier remarks that I thought the situation had settled down a bit from the period which was revealed in the Steel Industry Authority report. I went on to say that on 28 October a meeting was convened with the unions and BHP to try to resolve some of the issues anticipated as being likely causes of problems. I do not want to do anything to upset the possibility of those issues being resolved. It is easy for me to come in here and make inflammatory statements. Other Ministers have been accused of doing that. I do not propose to do that. I am optimistic that those issues can be resolved. If they cannot be, the course which BHP has, as a principal in this dispute, announced it will take, will inevitably follow; that is quite clear. But it will not follow, in my view, as a priority course of action. It would be much better if there could be some resolution of these issues and of how any necessary voluntary reductions in labour should be attained. It should be dealt with by discussion rather than by any process which is likely to follow if those discussions are not constructive and positive.

A number of other points have been made. Senator Michael Baume queried, I thought with great disrespect to the Chairman of the Steel Industry Authority-has the honourable senator ever tried to put anything over him? He should have a go at it some time if he wants to-why total man hours lost through industrial disputes had not been recorded in the annual report. Figures for total man hours lost are available in both annual reports. They are not analysed per employee in the annual report but they are in each of the quarterly reports. I am sorry if that involves the honourable senator in additional work, but they are all there in the quarterly reports. That is the answer to his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not tabled in this place, are they?
—The quarterly reports?
—Yes.
—Well, I think they have been.
—I have got one, but I don't know where I got it from. I might have got it from your office.
—No, they're not tabled in this place.

—They are available. They are public documents. Whether they are tabled or not is a different matter. Senator Stone gave us a folksy history of Newcastle, which I do not disagree with. He could apply that little history to most industrialised towns of the smokestack era.

—But the point of the history was to draw attention to the problem for your Government and your policy portfolio, particularly, of trade union power, and to point to the failure of your Government to deal with that properly.
—The honourable senator was not here at the time, but I can remember being in this chamber when the level of disputation was twice what it is now.
—The level of disputation is one issue, but it is by no means the really important issue.

—Yes. I can remember being here at a time when the honourable senator was Secretary to the Treasury, when the level of unemployment in this country was close to 11 per cent and when, over three years we had annual increases in wages of 12, 14 and 15 per cent. I can remember the times when people such as the honourable senator were waving their big sticks and magic wands and saying that all this could be wished away, but it did not happen. This Government, by comparison, has had relatively good results on each of those measures. I know he has flexed his muscles as --
—Perfectly good results which keep on having us go backwards in the world!
—Like at Peko Wallsend Ltd.
—If you want to talk about Peko Wallsend, there is a company which, by its own efforts, doubled productivity.
—Yes, and lost a Japanese market.
—Nonsense!
—It did indeed.

—I was in Japan at the time. I know what the Japanese thought about your company.
—How much are they shipping to Japan today, Senator? You should know that.
—I know what they think about the honourable senator and Peko Wall- send in Japan. But I do not want to get into--

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the Minister for what, on the whole, has been a fairly rational response to the issues being raised. SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that if there were any suggestion of any agreement that there should be no further reduction in employment levels at BHP, surely the Minister in charge would have heard of it. I have sufficient respect for him not to regard him as incompetent in this area, because he certainly stands out in this Government as a competent Minister, unlike the rest. I believe it is very important that the Minister has said he has no knowledge of any such undertaking. I am citing the general tone, manner and climate of this debate because I have reacted negatively to what I have seen in this chamber this morning. I believe that we have reverted to the old model of confrontation by throwing stale old arguments at one another across the chamber. I recall a statement by Sir Mark Oliphant when he opened the first national conference of the Australian Democrats. You might be aware, Mr Chairman, that he also chaired one of the foundation meetings of the Australian Democrats in the Melbourne Town Hall in 1977. In opening our first national conference he drew a potent analogy about our legislative chambers. He likened the situation to two gangs of bikies lining up against one another in some dark alley at night and reverting to tactics which were totally unthinking, fairly brutal and generally pretty destructive. I rose to make a contribution not about the content but about the manner of debate and to give notice that, as the spokesperson in this area, I will attempt to shift us away from that model and to do better than the two gangs of bikies analogy that was suggested to us by Sir Mark Oliphant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise some matters dealt with in the Estimates Committee A examination of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet regarding, in particular, the Bicentennial re-enactment and celebrations. It was interesting for me to sit for the first time on an Estimates committee. Indeed, the first full day of the hearings was enjoyable because to be able to celebrate my birthday and to discuss at the same time the birthday of a nation seemed quite appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The first item of some concern to me related to the First Fleet re-enactment, which is being privately sponsored as well as being sponsored by the Australian Bicentennial Authority (ABA) and receiving some contribution from the New South Wales State Government. It will arrive in time to sail into Sydney on 26 January, the important and historical date of the founding of the colony of New South Wales. The evidence given by the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority disclosed that the First Fleet will not be able to re-enact the landing because of a decision made by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Unsworth, and the New South Wales State Government. It seems unacceptable to me to attempt to rewrite history. I admit that there can be some sensitivities in regard to the celebration of our Bicentenary, but it seems to me that neither the truth nor indeed the spirit of the celebration of the Bicentenary is in any way followed by trying to deny that the landing took place and that the very existence of this nation is as a result of the founding of the colony of New South Wales on the eastern coast of Australia by Governor Phillip.

Mr Kirk said in his evidence that the ABA had a commitment of some $500,000 in the Fleet, which sailed from London and which indeed, having now left Mauritius, is sailing towards its final destination, and that he was concerned that the 11 ships reach their destination. He declined to become involved in the question of whether the re-enactment of the landing should take place, saying instead that he thought it proper that the State Government be allowed to make that decision. We are celebrating the Bicentenary as a national event. It represents the founding of the nation of Australia. It seems to me that it is in the national interest that we should see that landing take place and that we should not allow the fact that the Fleet has arrived to be subsumed by simply allowing it to sail out of the harbour later in the day with the flotilla of tall ships which, although they may be interesting to see, in fact are of no historical significance to Australia's Bicentennial at all.

I am always concerned when we attempt to deal with a difficult situation by trying to deny that it happened. In our early history many people who had convict ancestry pretended that that was not so. As we matured as a nation, people began to see that those who had founded this country had merit, whether they were convicts or not. Therefore, it is part of our maturing as a nation that we have been able to say that our convict ancestry is a fact and that it has indeed contributed to the nature and the culture of our nation. It further seems to me that not allowing a re-enactment of the landing to take place is again a sign of immaturity-a sign that we are not prepared to say, `Yes, this is how we arrived in this country. This is how we established our country'. There are certain problems arising from that which we have to address. Yes, there are questions concerning the Aboriginals, who were here prior to our arrival. But that does not mean that the Unsworth Government is entitled to attempt to rewrite history.

I compare the Unsworth Government's decision with one which was disclosed in an answer given to questions posed by Senator Short in the course of previous Estimates committee hearings. It was shown that a grant of some $53,000 had been made for a re-enactment of the voyage in a traditional vessel and landing of Macassans from Sulawesi. Indeed, this voyage was significant for the north of Australia and the Federal Government has seen fit to allocate money to allow that re-enactment of the voyage and lan-ding to take place. If one is going to award points for the historically truthful re-enactment of the establishment of our nation, perhaps the Darwin landing would score 10 points and the Sydney landing nil. Other matters of concern to me relating to the Bicentennial arose in the course of the Estimates hearings.

I would now like to refer to matters regarding the appropriations for the Office of the Status of Women. Subsequent to the Estimates hearings, I asked in the Senate of Senator Ryan a question in regard to grants made to various bodies, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) Working Women's Centre. I drew the Senate's attention to the fact that grants of some $15,000 each had been made to bodies such as the Country Women's Association and the National Council of Women but that a grant of some $40,000 had been made to the ACTU Working Women's Centre. It was interesting that an 18 February Press release put out by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) itemising Commonwealth grants to women's organisations duly included those $15,000 grants and lesser grants but that there was no mention of the $40,000 grant made at the same time to the ACTU Working Women's Centre. Senator Ryan subsequently answered a supplementary question relating to the size and membership of the various organisations. I found that information less than satisfactory to the degree that there was a claim that the ACTU Working Women's Centre represented in excess of one million women whereas the other bodies either did not know how many people they represented or gave a lesser figure. In a situation of de facto, as distinct from de jure, compulsory trade unionism in this country, it is unacceptable to claim that the group represents a membership in excess of one million people.

In raising these matters and drawing attention to the importance of, firstly, the Bicentenary and, secondly, the manner in which grants which seem to have a political tinge are given, I wanted to make the point-and make it clearly-that, as we draw close to the celebration of our 200th birthday, it is important that we have a proper regard for history and that political considerations, particularly the fact that the Unsworth Government is facing defeat at the polls, should not be allowed to colour the manner in which we celebrate our birthday.

TALK.START.PARA: —New financial reporting standards were involved in the documents presented to Senate Estimates committees this year, the results of which we are now debating. Those new standards were alleged to be an improvement, to provide more information to enable a better examination of the process of government by the Senate, which, of course, is our duty. The reality is that that is bunkum. We have got less information. This Government has set out to cover things up in this material in what I believe to be a most disgraceful way. It imposes greater burdens on senators who have to ask public servants for details which had, in the past, been presented. Even more serious, it means that we do not get the printed responses to these questions, which are invariably taken on notice at the Senate Estimates committees, until just a few days before we have this debate, and we do not have the chance to follow up with questions about why on earth some extraordinary changes have taken place in expenditure. This is revealed to us only when we eventually get the written responses to the questions we have asked. To present to the Senate as an improvement a situation which involves a significant and serious diminution in information is, I believe, a disgrace. I want to protest as strongly as I can about it. I quote from the report to the Senate of Estimates Committee A:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes, however, that in some areas a considerable amount of essential information on some items of expenditure was not readily identifiable or explained in the tables. Examples of this were estimates of expenditure on official entertainment by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-
no doubt we can understand the sensitivity in that area-
details of its expenditure on visits by foreign dignitaries and the costs of maintaining official establishments.

The significant point is that these were the very areas that I, as Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, pursued this Government about last year. As the report says, this lack of information applied particularly to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the estimates of which are before us at the moment, but it applied equally to other bodies, such as the Commission for the Future, where there was no break-up of the administrative expenses at the Estimates Committee hearing. We did not know until we found it out in response to questions on notice, that there had been a 28 per cent increase to $167,500 in the use of consultants by the Commission for the Future. We did not know, and still do not know, just what the costs to us of the commissioners in the Commission of the Future have been. We have been told in a written response how much it costs per day. I had asked specifically, `Where can we find the expenses of the commissioners themselves?'. That means the total expenses for the year. For any bureaucrat to pretend that it does not mean that I think is a nonsense.

I do not believe that the purposes of the Senate are being served by the new system nor, it seems in this instance in particular, by the refusal to acknowledge the burden of the questions we ask, which we are now forced to ask because of the absence of proper information in the basic material. I think it is absurd. In this context we can now understand why this information was not presented to us by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I have no philosophical objection at all to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet expending large amounts of money on hospitality in our bicentennial year. I have a massive philosophical objection to being denied, if you like, immediate access to that information by that information not being presented to the Estimates committees as part of the normal provision of detail of expenditure to which we have been accustomed in the past. I do not know why the Government feels some desperate necessity to cover up what it is going to spend during the Bicentennial.

Let me outline the magnitude of the increases. I eventually got the response to my questions which were taken on notice. Heaven knows why the bureaucracy would not have known what they would be at the time of the Estimates committee hearings. I cannot understand why the Minister would not have recognised that, as there was this significant reduction in the information available to us, we would be seeking it, and why the questions could not have been answered at the time.
