TALK.START.PARA: —I was using that as an example. That is a very silly response.
—I understood the honourable senator to be saying that he could not receive information on the Commission for the Future.
—I used that as an example and I will deal with that matter now at length, thank you.

—I was not meaning to mislead the honourable senator. I understood that the honourable senator was making that comment in the context of the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
—No, you misunderstood.

—If I misunderstood, naturally, I apologise. But I think the honourable senator has misrepresented the efforts of those who have gone into many hours and, no doubt, weeks of work in preparing these Estimates by accusing them and the Government of being deliberately involved in an intentional cover-up of the material that ought to be made available to honourable senators. It is our intention that all material should be made available. Indeed, as I have said, it is in response to the recommendations, the injunction, the imperative of the Finance and Government Operations Committee that the Estimates were presented in the general form in which honourable senators had to deal with them in these Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume complained that, at the time of the Estimates, he was unable to get a precise breakdown of how some $3.5m was to be spent on special events associated with the bicentenary celebrations. I understand-in fact I have the information in front of me-that that material was made available as soon as it could be compiled and it was sent to the Secretary of Senate Estimates Committee A on 5 November 1987 in response to several questions asked by that Committee. So the information is on the record and certainly is available to Senator Baume and other honourable senators who are interested.

Senator Baume made a particular attack on expenditure on official residences of the Prime Minister. In relation to Kirribilli, what has to be understood is that it was not that the Prime Minister declared the work urgent in order to get expenditure undertaken, but that he gave a direction that only urgent work be undertaken. There is quite a difference. The urgency was judged not by him but by others. The Official Establishments Trust has long recognised that Kirribilli House is in urgent need of repairs to remedy severe structural deficiencies caused in the main by problems associated with rising and falling damp. In the process of doing any such work, the Trust has recommended that the House be restored in a style which is sympathetic to its age and historical appearance, bearing in mind that it is an item on the Register of the National Estate.

The situation appears to have been as follows: the poor condition of the slate roof and inadequate existing external drainage have caused severe rising and falling damp. This has caused roofing, flooring and structural timbers to deteriorate to an extent where flooring in some areas, particularly the first floor, is considered to be dangerous. Because of damp problems, wall plaster, built-in furniture, and wall and floor coverings have deteriorated to an extent where replacement is necessary. Electrical and hydraulic services have also deteriorated because of age and water penetration. In the former case, it represents a potential hazard. It is on that basis that the expenditure was undertaken.

I understand that the third stage of the restoration project commenced in 1985-86. The restoration, as I say, is being completed in a way which is sympathetic to the age and historical importance of Kirribilli House, as shown by its being on the National Estate Register. I emphasise that the Prime Minister did not declare the work urgent in order to grab some money out of the Treasury. He directed that only urgent work be undertaken. That essential and urgent work is in accordance with the assessment by the Official Establishments Trust. That structural problem being remedied, the furnishing and display of the areas that have been structurally restored is then done in an authentic style.

The honourable senator brought up the question of security, particularly at the Lodge. I can assure the honourable senator-because at the moment I am working on security for the new Parliament House-that there are constraints which are recognised in respect of the financial parameters that we all have to keep in mind when allocating resources. But I do not think that any Australian would wish a situation to develop where the official residence of the Prime Minister-at which he is in almost continual residence, certainly during the parliamentary weeks and months of the year, and where his spouse and guests have their residence-would be in any way vulnerable or in some peril or jeopardy due to the lack of sufficient security. Security is ensured by a combination of the staff trained in the guarding function, electronic devices and other more discrete contributions by other agencies. Whilst the expenditure is not small, I assure the honourable senator that it undergoes scrutiny within the government expenditure review processes. It certainly has been justified within our processes.

I have other matters I wish to raise on this Department but they are not related to this specific section.

SPEECH.PARA: I am totally unsatisfied by the Minister's comment, when he read from the prepared material provided by the public servants advising him, that the Prime Minister had not declared urgent the work on Kirribilli House. Let us get to the bottom of this matter. The work was declared urgent in 1978 in a report. The report the Minister talks about by the committee that is in charge of looking after these things dates, as I recall, from either 1978 or 1979. According to that committee, the work has been urgent since then. But the person who declared it sufficiently urgent for work to proceed was the Prime Minister. To have this semantic nonsense that it was not declared urgent by the Prime Minister is so much bunkum that I can assume only that the Minister was not aware of the background when he read without demur or any condition whatsoever the briefing note which I believe is misleading and is aimed at misleading this place. The work, I repeat, was regarded as urgent in that report many years ago. The Prime Minister declared that this work which was urgent in 1978 should proceed-costing half a million dollars last year and a quarter of a million dollars this year-at this time of restraint.

There may be a sound case for arguing that in the bicentennial year Kirribilli House should receive a great deal of attention because it will be occupied by visiting people and should be as presentable as possible. If that is the defence, that is fine. But let us not have this phoney defence that suddenly the work was declared urgent, when it was declared urgent 11 years ago, to my knowledge. As I understand it, the previous Prime Minister took the view that, even though the work was important and should proceed, it should not proceed until the economy was in a better state because it would set a bad example. I would like to see examples of `restraint' that have affected the Prime Minister. In every instance in regard to his accommodation he has shown no restraint whatsoever. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Minister's tabling yesterday of the final report of the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract, a report which reveals an incredible saga of incompetence and mismanagement at senior levels of the Public Service across several different departments and for which no Minister is prepared to accept responsibility. Is it a fact that the report reveals that there was no submission to Cabinet to approve forward funding until a mere three weeks before the contract was awarded? Is it further a fact that the report finds that advice from the Australian Government Solicitor was deficient? Finally, I ask whether it is a fact that, at the time of letting the contract to Mr Amann, his company had:

QUESTION.PARA: an interest in one aircraft which was not licensed for commercial operations and he himself held a private pilot's licence only.

I ask whether the Minister will confirm that the Government's only response to this bizarre series of events, which puts at risk the surveillance of Australia's northern coastline and which involved $17m of taxpayers' funds, has been to say:
Relevant staff, including senior managers, will be counselled concerning the deficiencies noted in the report and appropriate training will be arranged.
Why has the Government decided that there will be no disciplinary action taken against, or penalty imposed on, any of the many public servants who share responsibility for this debacle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why Senator Vanstone feels the need for a preview of the urgency motion she is about to move. Most of the matters she has raised will, of course, be debated later today. Could I just say in reponse to her question that, yes, of course the final Menzies report has revealed a number of evident deficiencies in public administration which lay behind the original awarding of the contract. Those deficiencies have been acknowledged in almost identical terms by me almost from the outset of this matter and certainly since we made it clear that we were terminating the contract and setting in train a full review of the processes which led to this whole matter taking place. So the Menzies report has done no more than confirm what I have already acknowledged, on the basis of my own previous investigation, to have been the case and which I have already explained on numerous occasions in this Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the specifics of Senator Vanstone's question, yes, it is the case that the approval for the forward funding was not sought from Cabinet until three weeks before the contract was awarded. The Menzies report has recommended that in future forward funding be sought before the tender process is in fact commenced. I indicated yesterday-I do so again now-that that recommendation, along with all the other recommendations of the Menzies report, is agreed to by me, and that will be the situation in the future.

Secondly, yes, the report does indicate that the advice received as to the structure of the tender document was deficient in some respects as it came to us from the Attorney-General's Department. Those deficiencies have been noted and acknowledged and they will not recur, but the circumstances of them did not materially or significantly contribute to the difficulties that arose in relation to this particular contract. That has been made clear by Mr Menzies and I do not think I need to track over that in any more detail at this stage, although I will be happy to do so later in the day.

As to the third part of the question, yes, the Menzies report did state what has been clear all along; that at the time of the awarding of the tender Amann Aviation Pty Ltd was only at best in possession of one aircraft. In fact, it was in possession of no aircraft of the type that was necessary for the conduct and performance of the contract. However, as I have made clear on previous occasions-and I do so again now-that in itself was no reason why the contract should not have been awarded to an organisation which was otherwise well equipped to get its act together in the time available to it to acquire the aircraft and the necessary aviation expertise to make the contract work, provided that organisation had managerial ability, access to lines of credit and access to reliable supply.

They were the conditions that had to be satisfied if a contract such as this were to be effectively performed and the tender obligations met. In practice, those preconditions were not satisfied, and it is in that respect that the maladministration here lay. The Menzies report does no more in this respect than spell out exactly the points of that kind that I have been making from day one in this particular respect.

So far as the question of disciplinary action is concerned in relation to those officers of various departments whose performance was less than optimal in this particular affair, the Menzies report has made its own judgment-it has done so with no axe of any kind to grind-that disciplinary action would not appear to be demanded by the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is only the taxpayers, the people of Australia and the defence of Australia. Why worry?

—Senator Chaney, with all the moral rectitude that he brings to bear from his great height on these occasions, might believe that after-the-event punishment is a satisfactory course. The people involved in this affair have already been punished, in ways that are well known to Senator Messner and Senator Durack-and I do not propose to make them public in this place-in terms of the impact that this whole unhappy affair has had on their personal health and career prospects. I do not propose to embark upon a sordid, tawdry witch-hunt because of some sanctimony from a twerp like Senator Chaney on an occasion like this. I propose to respond, as I have throughout this matter, in a way which is measured and balanced, which reflects a proper sense of responsibility for due and effective public administration. To the extent that deficiencies have been identified, they have been acknowledged and rectified, or are in the process of being rectified. No more action could reasonably be demanded of any government and of any Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to a Press report yesterday which read:

QUESTION.PARA: Qantas, Singapore Airlines and Thai International have agreed to increase their scheduled flights to and from Australia . . .
The Australian carrier has finally come to agreement with the two airlines after 12 months of negotiations . . .
Can the Minister provide details of those agreements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas Airways Ltd and Singapore Airlines Ltd, during talks which concluded in Sydney yesterday, agreed to recommend to their respective governments significant additional capacity and new route opportunities. The agreement provides for up to seven extra Boeing 747 flights a week. Five of these will be permitted to operate from 1 December-two by Singapore Airlines and three by Qantas. Each airline will be permitted to operate a further 747 weekly service from, at the latest, April 1989. The airlines will meet by April 1988 to determine whether, in light of traffic growth, these additional services should be brought forward to August next year.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the increased capacity, and very importantly, the airlines have agreed to major changes to their route entitlements. Singapore Airlines will have the right to operate services to Cairns and Townsville and Qantas will have the right to an additional two points beyond Singapore, to be selected from a number of points in Asia. This agreement follows the successful discussions that Qantas concluded with Thai International Airways last week, which led to an agreement to operate up to five more 747 flights each week between Australia and Thailand. Three of these may commence in April 1988 and the additional two in April 1989. In addition, there are route entitlements associated with that agreement which will have a similar effect as far as the two airlines are concerned.

I congratulate Qantas on the very considerable effort that has been put into achieving these very important understandings, which obviously provide major additional capacity for services to meet this rapidly growing market for air travel into Australia. The successful negotiations that I have referred to are part of the quite herculean effort that Qantas has been putting into improving capacity to Australia in both the short term and the long term. It has already been stated, and I do so again, that Qantas has made a massive effort to relieve short term pressures on the system at the moment by operating, with Government approval, more than 160 supplementary flights over the present summer peak period. That is quite a dramatic increase on the 50 such flights which operated during the corresponding period last year.

On the longer term front, in addition to the agreements with Thai and Singapore to which I have just referred, other very substantial negotiations have been proceeding with airlines in a number of other countries which have either borne fruit in the recent past or are expected to in the near future. In particular, as far as Japan is concerned, over the last two years there has been a quite dramatic explosion in the number of services, which has expanded from six per week just two years ago to 19 per week at the moment, with another two coming up shortly in the New Year.

I summarise by saying that, since the election of the Hawke Government in 1983, an additional 800,000 international airline seats have been introduced to the inbound aviation market to Australia through this bilateral negotiating process. By the middle of next year this figure will rise to over 1 1/4 million. That represents an increase in inbound capacity of about 36 per cent over that period. I am talking about permanent increases in capacity, not the temporary increases that flow with seasonal peaks, and the addition of supplementary flights of the kind to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I note that the final report of the Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract has made 10 recommendations concerning future conduct of the tendering process of the Minister's Department. Given that this process, which developed into a fiasco which included several departments, is but one of many exercises carried out every year by the Commonwealth Public Service, I ask: has action been initiated to review tendering processes in all departments of the Public Service? If not, why not? What guarantee is there that other departments are not operating in a similarly defective way to that which occurred in the former Department of Transport over the coastwatch contract?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no reason to suppose that there are any fundamental weaknesses in the tendering process as it operates elsewhere in the Public Service-certainly not in the major departments, Administrative Services and Defence, both of which were represented during the Menzies review process, which are the departments that engage in by far the greatest number of sophisticated and high value tenders.
—Give us a lecture on it.

—I will give Senator Lewis a few lectures but I will save them for outside this chamber, otherwise I might find myself engaged in unparliamentary behaviour. The point that particularly needs to be made about the Department of Transport, as it then was, finding itself running a complicated tender of this kind, is that it was not a scale of operation which that Department was accustomed to handling. It was used to handling comparatively minor order purchases, which tended to be packages of goods rather than services, and certainly not projects of this degree of complexity and difficulty.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular administrative deficiencies that have been acknowledged by me from the outset and that have shown up and been confirmed in the Menzies report released yesterday, are deficiencies, essentially, of a minor league player in the tender and acquisition process finding itself with a major league game in front of it. In short, that was the problem. The processes of the Commonwealth as a whole, with the supply manuals and the very elaborate checking processes that are built into the Commonwealth's procedures elsewhere, were simply not familiar to-it has become perfectly apparent-the departmental officers who were engaged in dealing with this contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't worry about the departmental officers. What about the Minister?
—I have not been asked about the Minister. If you want to get up, boofhead, and ask me a question about the Minister, I will be perfectly happy to answer it.
—Order!

—I will withdraw without being asked, Mr President. I appreciate that that represented a lapse on my part which I will endeavour not to repeat, whatever the provocation. When I am asked questions about Ministers, I will answer accordingly. At the moment I am being asked only about bureaucratic processes, tendering processes. I have endeavoured to explain the reason for my confidence that problems of this kind are not endemic in the Public Service generally as well as being, of course, highly unlikely to recur in my own Department as a result of the lessons that have obviously been learnt from this exercise.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister invites me to ask about his own role in this matter, I note that on page 10 of the report on Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, Mr Menzies draws our attention to the fact that, in the final analysis, it falls to the decision-maker to decide what is an acceptable risk to the Commonwealth. Did the Minister decide on that issue in this case?

—The Minister did not decide on that issue in this case. That is made perfectly clear if one reads the report. There was not put to the Minister, or any of the Ministers who were acting in Mr Morris's stead when the particular series of decisions was made, any of the considerations that would have alerted them to the fact that there was some risk associated with the grant of this contract. All of that is fully spelt out. If the matters in issue had been put with any clarity or in any detail to Mr Morris or to Mr Scholes, who was acting on his behalf in his absence overseas at the relevant time, or to the further Minister-I think it was Mr Duffy-who finally took the matter through Cabinet, all of whom are identified and mentioned in the report, and if the Ministers had been briefed on some of the matters which did apparently cause concern in some breasts but not the relevant ones at the relevant time, of course they would have made some assessment themselves of the risk involved and made a decision accordingly. The circumstances are perfectly well known, perfectly clearly spelt out, and I do not think they require any more defence from me than is articulated in the Menzies report itself.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday headed ` ``Throw out drug children'' is videotape message'? This newspaper article implies that the primary focus of the videotape Don't Be The Last to Know, which has been produced by the Government as part of the drug offensive program, is to force drug addicted children out of their parental homes. Is this a fair or accurate account of this video? Is the Minister also aware that this video is to be screened in every State in Australia at 7.30 p.m. on Sunday, but not in Canberra? What is the reason for this exception?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a brief from the Minister for Community Services and Health and I would like to acquaint the chamber with it. The Minister is aware of the article and is pleased to inform Senator Zakharov that throwing drug addicted children out of their parental homes is not in any way the primary focus of the film. In fact, the main message from the film is about the need for communication within the family, the need for parents and children to talk to each other and together deal with problems of drug abuse.

ANSWER.PARA: Don't Be The Last To Know has been produced by the drug offensive in association with Film Australia and is narrated by Mike Willesee. The film concentrates on the experience of two young people who were drug dependent, one on alcohol and the other on heroin, the effects on them and their families and their ultimate success in overcoming their problems. They are true stories and real people. The film makes it clear that drug abuse is very often the symptom of a problem rather than the cause, and it encourages honest and open communication within the family setting to help young people to deal with the temptations and problems of drugs.

The film explains that help is available not only for the individual with a drug abuse problem but also for the family and friends who may be swept up in that problem. In the two cases shown, the parents did ultimately eject their children from home and, by making them responsible for their own actions, forced them to confront their own drug problems and to deal with them. However, this was after a very long battle with their addictions, and the film very explicitly stresses that this may not be the right thing to do-that it will depend on the circumstances of the problem and the advice received. The Minister urges all Australian parents to watch Don't Be The Last To Know with their children-I emphasise `with their children'-when it premiers on the National 9 network in the top rating 60 Minutes time slot this Sunday night. This should ensure it a significant viewing audience throughout Australia and I commend Channel 9 for its decision to screen it at that time.

As Senator Zakharov indicated, unfortunately the people of Canberra will be deprived of seeing it because, even though Capital 7 runs Willesee and 60 Minutes, it has so far refused to show the film. I urge it to quickly change its mind.

Finally, the Video Industry Distributors Association of Australia deserves special credit for the vital community service role it is playing by distributing the film. Thanks to the video industry, Don't Be The Last To Know will be available free of charge to concerned families through the network of 3,000 video retail outlets throughout Australia. I understand that this is at a cost to the video industry of about $150,000 and that it is the first time that such a drug education film has been released through video outlets anywhere in the world. Copies of Don't Be The Last To Know will be circulated to all honourable members and senators and I urge them all to publicise its availability. I commend Don't Be The Last To Know to all Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Government considering abandoning its proposed changes to the criteria for defence service home loans? Is the Minister aware that a change from the present loan to a $10,000 non-repayable, non-taxable cash grant would considerably increase the financial burden on service men and women, especially veterans, who generally are older and therefore are forced to pay back loans at a higher rate? In order to put an end to the confusion and inconvenience experienced since the Budget by defence personnel and veterans in the process of negotiating to purchase a home, will the Government announce its intentions on this change as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by Mr Humphreys that the Government has received a submission from the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL). In view of the importance the Government attaches to the defence veterans' conditions and the extremely tight timeframe within which a decision on the matter is to be made, the Government has appointed a businessman, Mr John Alan Uhrig, to head a group of senior officials from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Defence and the Department of Finance, together with a representative of the RSL, to examine and report on this matter. The aim of the group is to look constructively at the Government's proposal, along with the variations that have been proposed by the RSL and other interested bodies, with a view to presenting an urgent report. It is intended that the report will be available in time for it to be considered by the Government, with a view to an announcement of a final decision before the end of the year.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the precise effect of the change on older service men and women and veterans, it is not the Government's intention that the proposal disadvantage any eligible persons. Senator McLean will be aware that the $10,000 grant represents the lump sum equivalent of the interest subsidy which is currently paid by the Government on the average defence service home loan. It is based on an interest rate of 13.5 per cent over a typical term of 17 years. Let me quote from Senator Walters, whose advice on a number of matters is always important to reflect on. In the Senate Estimates committee on 29 October 1987 she said, `That sounds fair enough'. I reiterate that it is not the Government's intention to disadvantage any eligible person. An announcement will be made before the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware that on 23 October 1987 two officers of the Department of Administrative Services, Messrs Ross Temple and Colin Ekert, spoke with Peter Martin, owner of the land near Geraldton which the Government seeks to compulsorily seize for its spy base there, and indicated that the value of the project was of the order of $300m, not the $25m which has been officially stated? Were Messrs Temple and Ekert authorised to give this figure? If so, is the figure accurate? Is the Minister also aware that on 26 October 1987 a Mr Mark Appelt, an engineer with the Department of Housing and Construction, sought access to the Martin land and indicated in the process that $300m was a probable all-up cost if housing and so on were included? Was this figure cleared with Administrative Services before Appelt used it? Finally, I ask: What is the estimated project cost of the Geraldton spy base?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I do not have a quote from Senator Walters to assist me here, but I have some notes on the subject. The officers from the Department of Administrative Services who have spoken to land owners in the Geraldton area were certainly not authorised to give out any information about the total project cost of the new planned facility, nor do they have access to that information. This applies equally to those officers of the former Department of Housing and Construction. I wish to make it quite clear also that the land in the Geraldton area is not being compulsorily seized. Land will be acquired through the normal government land acquisition procedures. All costings have been properly and thoroughly reviewed by the security committee of Cabinet.

ANSWER.PARA: The facility, as previously stated in the Parliament, will provide a substantial increase in Australia's independent intelligence gathering capabilities. The defence policy information paper tabled in March this year stresses that such a capability is fundamental to our national security and the Government will ensure that our needs for strategic intelligence of high quality will continue to be met. Our intelligence gathering capabilities will be staff operated and controlled by Australians. It is not the practice of governments to release the specific costs of those intelligence capabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understood the Minister to say that it is not customary for the Government to outline the costs of such intelligence gathering operations. Is that the final word on this matter? The Government should be able to give final costings of the Geraldton project and I think they should be supplied to the landowners and the Parliament as soon as possible. Will this information not be forthcoming?
—I did not refer to global costs, in any event; I said `the specific costs'. I am advised by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, that it is not his intention to release those specific costs.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, concerns the extraordinary incompetence-incompetence which was denied heatedly by the Minister responsible for this matter at the time, Senator Gietzelt, in this place and in Estimates committee hearings-revealed by the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract. Is it a fact that the review committee found that the general attitude of the Tender Assessment Committee, as explained by its Chairman, was `not consistent with Commonwealth policy as to assessing tenders of such magnitude and complexity'? What is the nature of the counselling and training to which the Chairman and other members of the Committee will be exposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact, as I said in answer to an earlier question, that the understanding and appreciation of the departmental officers concerned of what was involved in the proper application of tender principles was not what it should have been. In particular, they failed to appreciate that it was not a matter of just giving the contract to the lowest cost conforming tenderer; that there had to be an absolutely rigorous evaluation of the capacity of that tenderer to deliver, particularly in the context not of an off-the-shelf tender performance but of the provision of services of a complex kind over a long period. There was a failure to appreciate the extent of the Commonwealth tendering rules, as contained in detailed manuals and procedural instructions that exist elsewhere within the system. There was not a full and complete understanding of the way in which those principles should be applied to a complex tender of this kind.

ANSWER.PARA: The form that the counselling and training will take will obviously make certain in the first place that any of the officers who are engaged in these kinds of tender assessments in the future are totally and fully apprised of the ground rules, principles and procedures that should apply to contract proposals of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not counselling; it is training. It has nothing to do with counselling.

—I am referring to the training that will be necessary for the future, if the honourable senator can get himself back down off his high horse for the second time this Question Time. The officers will be trained in the proper principles and procedures that apply to this proposal. There will also be a standing requirement of consultation with, in the case of major tender assessments, other departments and other senior officers elsewhere in the system who have greater familiarity or experience with these matters than has traditionally been the case in my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the counselling that will be given to those officers whose performance, as I said earlier, has been somewhat less than optimal in this respect, those who find it possible to resume their duties after the trauma to which they have been subjected by this affair--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, the poor fellow. What absolutely pathetic behaviour.

—Senator Chaney can sneer, sigh and carry on. I will have a word with him later. He is oozing with sanctimony for the umpteenth time in his parliamentary career, and is doing so in a peculiarly unattractive fashion. I will tell him a little of the background that underlies this matter and we will see how much Christian compassion he can then bring to bear, rather than talking about it on occasions such as this.
—Have you ever thought of your responsibility to the country?

—I think of it all the time, and that is why I am standing here and why the honourable senator is in opposition and will remain so for as long as any of us is performing effectively in this place. There are a number of deficiencies at a number of different levels, deficiencies on the part of officers engaged in full time operational capacities and, clearly, deficiencies in supervision and oversight by more senior management. Obviously, those deficiencies will also be remedied by appropriate and systematic counselling, appropriate and systematic talking through and working through the lessons that can be learned from an exercise of this kind.

ANSWER.PARA: Problems do occur in administrations from time to time. Senator Chaney, Senator Durack, Senator Messner and others may remember that some problems occurred on a massive scale during their administration, problems that cost this country hundreds of millions of dollars in irretrievably lost tax revenue. Absolutely nothing was lost to the country by this particular exercise. Not a day of coastwatch surveillance performance has been lost and not a dollar of Commonwealth money has gone down the drain as a result of this affair, unlike the hundreds of millions of dollars that are directly attributable not just to low order bureaucratic failures but to high order failures of ministerial oversight, government direction and government competence. That is what was lacking in Senator Chaney's day. He has learned nothing from the experience and as a result he will bear the fruits of that in the Australian electorate into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the people who were in charge of this Department-presumably they were on very high salaries-make the obvious mistakes that have been made when they were warned continually by honourable senators on this side of the chamber and at Estimate committee hearings six months before the disaster happened?
—Because those officers probably pay as much attention to you as the rest of the electorate do, which is to say, none at all.
—I think Senator Collins has given the perfect supplementary response and I will leave it at that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Have there been any recent Australian initiatives at the United Nations General Assembly in relation to a comprehensive test ban treaty? If so, what has been the response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some dramatic initiatives have been taken by the Australian delegation at the United Nations and the response has been outstandingly successful. An Australia-New Zealand resolution calling for a comprehensive test ban treaty and practical work on associated issues was adopted by an overwhelming majority in the First Committee of the United Nations General Assembly on 13 November. The resolution gained the support of 122 nations and was opposed only by the United States and France. It attracted more support than other resolutions calling for the cessation of nuclear test explosions. It included a specific call for the development of an international seismic monitoring network that would be essential to the verification regime required for a comprehensive test ban treaty. An Australian resolution on the notification of details of nuclear tests to the Secretary-General was also adopted by a large majority. The Australian delegation has been displaying conspicuous and very effective leadership in the carrying forward of these crucially important issues of principle and practice as far as disarmament is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's leading influence in the international debate on disarmament issues was also reflected in the adoption by consensus in the First Committee on 12 November of an Australian initiative against the use of chemical weapons. The chemical weapons resolution calls on all states to observe the 1925 Geneva protocol banning the use of chemical and biological weapons. It requests the Secretary-General to investigate reports of use brought to his attention and to report his findings to member states. Prompt and impartial investigations of reports will, of course, enhance the authority of the Geneva protocol.

The resolution also supports the negotiations currently under way in Geneva for a comprehensive chemical weapons convention. Particularly new ground broken by this resolution is the universal support for the Secretary-General's role. In the past this has been opposed by many countries, including the Soviet Union. Once again, the effectiveness of Australian diplomacy and leadership in this area and the credibility that the Australian Government has won in the last 4 1/2 years by its dedicated pursuit of disarmament issues through, in particular, the efforts of the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Butler, have borne fruit on this occasion in a way which should, I think, attract the support of all members of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, who might more appropriately be called the Minister for mates and double standards, relates to the shoddy and ineffectual procedures followed by the Government with respect to the coastwatch tender and to the portrayal of the national interest that that represented. Does the Minister agree that the Minister responsible for the Department of Transport during most of the time the coastwatch contract was under discussion knew that his officers were working on the matter? If that is so, under the principle of ministerial responsibility, on which we have heard so much from the Minister in the past, why should Mr Morris not take full responsibility for the extraordinary bungling and incompetence revealed in the report of the Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract fiasco? Why should Mr Morris be excused for having failed to interest himself sufficiently in the tender renewal process, especially when the matter had reached very senior levels in his Department? Why should he escape the fact that he chose to ask none of the obvious and relevant questions that a serious Minister would ask?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the last time in Westminster parliamentary history that a Minister resigned as a result not of any personal malfeasance or negligence on his behalf but merely that of maladministration within his own department was the Crichel Down affair in Great Britain. Senator Puplick will no doubt correct me if I am wrong on this subject. He is already purporting to but he is wrong about that example. The last example was, I think, over three decades ago in Great Britain. Subsequently, there have been periodic bits of grandstanding in the way of offers to resign which have been carefully orchestrated in advance to ensure that they will not be accepted but in terms of actual instances of Ministers accepting that extreme degree of responsibility that is no longer the accepted convention and it is acknowledged as such in both countries.

ANSWER.PARA: I would welcome a supplementary question from Senator Chaney if he has any examples of Ministers in his own previous Government resigning on the grounds of the loss of several hundreds of millions of dollars through the bottom of the drawer tax scandal or, if he can think of any other illustrations where Ministers have responded to their responsibility to the public wheel, I would be delighted to hear from him. The truth of the matter is otherwise. It is only when there is some personal element of misbehaviour or negligence that the principle of individual ministerial responsibility is presently accepted. Senator Puplick ought to know about that because he contributed to a chapter to that effect in a Senate committee report I wrote with him some years ago. In the particular case of the Ministers involved in this matter, the truth is very well set out on pages 56 to 58 of the Menzies committee report which bears upon the particular involvement that Ministers had in the conduct of this matter as it came before them. It is most simply summarised, I suppose, in the third paragraph on page 58 where it is said:
The very limited information on this aspect-
that is to say the lack of expertise and the risks associated with that-

provided to Ministers did not alert them to the dangers presented by the lack of expertise on the part of Amann and his staff and the absence of any existing organisation. The unreliability of the costings investigation was also not revealed.

The truth of the matter is that none of the signals that might reasonably have been expected to have been communicated to the relevant Ministers were in fact communicated as a result of the combination of circumstances that are fully described in this report. Under those circumstances no Minister can be expected to assume the degree of personal responsibility for things that go wrong that Senator Chaney is claiming, with all the hypocrisy he can muster on these occasions, should be the case. That is simply not the way things have been done in memory in the Australian environment in the past and I am sure it will not be what will happen in the future either. There is absolutely nothing here that represented any lapse of judgment, quite apart from any worse form of negligence or misbehaviour on the part of any of the Ministers that were involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which relates to the Minister's reference to signals to Ministers. Does he deny that the signals of concern that were expressed in this chamber to Senator Gietzelt on a continual basis were treated with contempt by the Minister and totally rejected by him?

—I deny that absolutely. I also referred to the fact that those particular signals were, such as they were, signals that were given after the contract had been awarded-well after-and not at the time that we are talking about when the contract was granted in the first instance.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a speech made by Treasury Secretary Stone, now Senator Stone, on 19 November 1979 to the Australian Institute of Management? In that speech did Senator Stone lay down a series of what he described as unchallengeable propositions in relation to the management of the nation's current account in the 1980s which makes this question quite relevant? Do those unchallengeable propositions still underpin this Government's economic strategy and should those unchallengeable propositions also underpin Senator Stone's eventual run for the leadership of the Parliamentary National Party foreshadowed on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have a copy of the speech delivered by the then Treasury Secretary on 19 November 1979. I would like to quote a few extracts from it. Of what was then known as the `Gregory thesis', which I will not explain but it was getting a lot of publicity at the time, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the expectation of a strong growth of mineral exports on which they were based-
`they' being the conclusions of Gregory-

and an expectation I agree with. I want also to note that even in the brief time since those figures were current the outlook for energy exports has immeasurably strengthened. In short, in the decade ahead there seems every reason to believe that we are going to be very successful at exporting. That brings me to my first major point, which is this: The more successful in the decade ahead we prove to be at exporting, the more successful we are also going to have to be at importing.
He then went on to say with characteristic modesty:
It is important to understand that this conclusion does not rest upon my opinion or some other equally unreliable foundation, but upon a simple chain of logic.
He also said:
. . . Australia will need to sustain a deficit on the current account of its balance of payments through the 1980s . . .
Towards the end of the speech he said, again with characteristic modesty:

I am conscious that in developing this paper I have, in my effort to ensure the logical undeniability of the series of propositions it advances, almost necessarily been forced into complexities. Let me therefore try to draw out the chief points by now posing three simple questions:

Since drawing on external capital means obtaining imports now on the basis of paying for them later with deferred exports, why, if we wish (or need) to acquire capital from abroad, would we either especially limit imports?-or still less, encourage exports?

If however, we do wish to encourage exports-or if matters (eg, the international energy situation) should so develop as to ensure that exports increase anyway, why-since the purpose of exporting lies in acquiring the wherewithal to purchase imports-would we wish to limit imports?
If however we do, for whatever reason, wish to limit imports, why would we wish to especially encourage exports?

Anybody who had been listening to that would have noticed a certain incompatibility between the views that the then Treasury Secretary held in 1979 about a current account deficit and the views he appears to hold now. In other words, his economic pontifications rest upon a very flawed historical record, as indeed do his moral pontifications. Ultimately he should be judged against the background of a sleazy Queensland National Party machine which put him into Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Foreman in his capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Infrastructure. Can Senator Foreman advise the Senate what progress his Committee has made on the reference given to it by the Senate on 24 September last concerning the coastwatch contract debacle? Is it the Committee's intention to conduct public hearings into this sorry affair?

—The Committee has met on three occasions and on the first occasion the Committee decided to await the second Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the Coast-watch Contract. The Committee met this morning and decided to have a review of the Menzies report, and we hope that that hearing will start some time next week.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question arising out of that answer. I would like Senator Foreman to give the Senate an assurance that the Committee investigations will not be restricted to the excessively narrow terms of the Menzies committee, and will in fact follow the reference given by the Senate two months ago.

—I am sure that the Committee will take into consideration the directions that were given to it by the Senate some weeks ago and will also consider all aspects of the review and everything else that may be relevant to the inquiry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) retail sales statistics for September, which were released yesterday? Is it true that over the year to September, Queensland has been the worst performing State in terms of retail sales growth? Would Australia's overall macroeconomic performance be better if business and consumer confidence in Queensland were running at rates closer to the national average?

—The answer to the last part of the question is, of course, yes. I am sure that that will not surprise Senator Burns. The answer to the first part of the question is also yes. Indeed, over the last 12 months ending September 1987, retail sales growth, in terms of current prices in the new series published by the ABS, shows that the Australian average increase was 8.1 per cent. The highest was Western Australia with 9.7 per cent and the lowest of all was Queensland, with 6.9 per cent. The other States necessarily fell between 6.9 per cent and 9.7 per cent. Some might see those figures as not necessarily being bad news if they were an indication of a transfer of income from consumption to investment, which in the macroeconomic sense is something which Australia as a nation does need. When they are taken in conjunction with the appalling Queensland business investment statistics, published two weeks ago by the ABS, it seems much more likely that a different situation is present; that is, that the Bjelke-Petersen regime purports to encourage private enterprise and the private sector in general, but the reality is that the only people who get encouragement are some of its cronies. In conclusion, it should be noted that apparently some business activities have been thriving in Queensland recently and, given the publicity that has been given to them in recent times, and the compliant attitude of the authorities in Queensland, they should continue to do very well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. He will recall being responsible for inserting a number of advertisements in Queensland local newspapers under the heading, `What I have been trying to say about the World Heritage listing: the uninterrupted version'. The advertisement appears over Senator Richardson's personal signature, and I therefore assume that he is familiar with its text. He will also acknowledge the fact that he had to have this advert reprinted in order to exclude a photograph of a particular Australian citizen who objected to his photograph being included in the advert. Senator Richardson will recall that he says in the advert:

QUESTION.PARA: When trees which have taken hundreds of years to grow are felled, or loggers' roads bulldozed through, the canopy is pierced by sunlight and a different kind of rainforest begins to grow.
Plants which are not indigenous to the rainforest then take hold and, like weeds, take over.
I ask Senator Richardson: Which species of plants?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to answer that question. I received in the mail a couple of days ago a present from a resident of Ravenshoe, and when a person in my position receives presents from a resident of Ravenshoe one wonders what sort of present one is receiving.
—Have you declared it?

—No, I have not declared it, but I am doing so now. I cannot recall the exact Latin term that the gentleman used in referring to the plant, but he, being a local timber man, well and truly involved for much of his life in the forest, said that this was the first plant to regenerate after logging and he sent me a leaf because he wanted us to make it the emblem for the world heritage area.
—He wanted you to wrap yourself around it.

—No, Senator Boswell, your problem is that you have been sitting on it for too long. The plant turns out to be called the gympie-gympie, which is a stinging plant which I am told has been known to cause fatalities. When one is stung by it, the pain can last for one to two years, and it takes 40 years for the leaf, when cut off the plant, to lose its potency. That is the first plant to come up and I might say that I am going to take a considerable interest in the legality of forwarding such a plant to me in those circumstances. —I wish to ask a supplementary question.
