INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 20 November, from Senator Vanstone:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to accept responsibility at both political and bureaucratic level for the gross mismanagement revealed by the Menzies Report into the Coastwatch contract fiasco, instead of the whitewash proposed by the Minister for Transport and Communications which provides no satisfaction to the taxpayers of Australia who have seen public funds and the security of the northern coastline put at risk by Ministerial and official incompetence.''
Senator for the State of South Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: ``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to accept responsibility at both political and bureaucratic level for the gross mismanagement revealed by the Menzies Report into the Coastwatch contract fiasco, instead of the whitewash proposed by the Minister for Transport and Communications which provides no satisfaction to the taxpayers of Australia who have seen public funds and the security of the northern coastline put at risk by Ministerial and official incompetence.''

During Question Time today I understood the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) to say that this matter, this fiasco, does not raise questions of ministerial responsibility. Unless I am unfairly paraphrasing him, he says that if there is no malfeasance or negligence, ministerial responsibility does not arise. I accept that there might be none of the former, but I do not accept that there is none of the latter. The Minister says there was not one day of surveillance lost and no dollars lost as a consequence of this bureaucratic bungling.

I draw the Minister's attention to what would have been the cost of the first inquiry-the first Menzies report-the cost of the second inquiry, and the cost of the Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure inquiry. If the cost of all those inquiries is simply par for the course, I draw the Minister's attention to the cost of the additional loading of the contract of Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd for an extension of the services while this bungle was being sorted out, an extension that had to be required because of the bungling and ineptitude of the then Department of Transport, an extension that was sought three or four times. Three or four times the previous contractor was asked to extend the contract because of the difficulties with the new contractor, Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. Eventually Skywest, as I understand it, successfully sought a loading on the contract to cope with the uncertainty. We are not talking about just a paper uncertainty; we are talking about real people wanting to know whether they have a job in the next month or the month thereafter, real people wanting to know about the future of their employment and suffering the stress associated therewith. It is perhaps not a dollar cost, but nonetheless it is an important one.

I draw the Minister's attention to the impending legal action and the claim by Amann Aviation against the Government. I can make no assessment of what that cost is going to be, but if I were in the Minister's shoes I would not be so confident that this fiasco is not going to cost, or has not yet cost, this Government any dollars. If, however, Madam Acting Deputy President, you accept that there is no loss-I am sure you understand that the Opposition does not accept that-is the Minister saying therefore that there is no ministerial responsibility in this question?

I want to put an analogy before the Senate, and I hope that that analogy adequately conveys my view. I take the example of a would-be murderer who intends to shoot to kill. He comes up to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, points the gun, shoots and misses. By the grace of God you escape death-sheer luck or perhaps ineptitude. Is the would-be murderer completely innocent? Do we say, `Oh, well, there has been no harm done. Off you go on your way. Have another shot next week.'? Of course we do not, because the murderer intended to kill. The victim was saved by sheer luck. The analogy I draw is of incompetent Ministers and incompetent administrators who, by the same stroke of luck or divine intervention, are saved from witnessing the real financial consequences of their incompetence, but that incompetence is nonetheless still there.

This saga displays incompetence by Ministers and senior public servants, and all the Minister says is that public servants will be counselled. What the Opposition would like to know is: Who will counsel the Ministers involved? Senator Evans, was not the Minister at the time; I understand that. However, I seem to recall that as a consequence of some spy flights over Tasmania, he acquired a nickname that befits him well now. I think that it was `Biggles'. He potters around the issues in what his colleagues may see as an admirable attempt to protect them and the Public Service. But what the public and the Opposition see is a stubborn refusal of his Government to accept responsibility for a fiasco in administration. The Government cannot get out of that by claiming that the cost has been minimal. The fiasco in administration is there and the ineptitude is there. Menzies' final report outlines clearly numerous examples of gross incompetence.

The Minister makes much of the report not recommending disciplinary action. I draw the Minister's attention to the terms of reference which, as I understand it, ask for changes that should be made to improve procedures. That is exactly what the report suggests. I do not see in the terms of reference a request that the committee consider what, if any, disciplinary action ought to be taken. I presume that that is not in the terms of reference because everyone understood in the beginning that that decision is for the Government to make-the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The first finding was that no evidence of corruption or illegal conduct was found. I do not want to make a big deal of that recommendation, but I say simply that I and members of the public would be more comfortable with that finding if the report indicated evidence of inquiries that had been made to ascertain whether or not that was so. Or do we take the finding to mean simply that because the inquiry did not stumble upon such things, it assumed they were not there?

The Opposition claims that the Government should have shown extra care in the awarding of this tender and that it should have done so because of the lack of experience of Amann Aviation. No one on this side says that a person should be deprived of the opportunity of gaining experience. That is not the point at all. The point we have made from day one is that an important, expensive contract was awarded to an inexperienced person in the industry and that that should have rung bells in the minds of the public servants concerned-that perhaps there were problems. I well recall the debate on this matter in May when Government members sought to portray my Opposition colleagues as being people who wanted to persecute newcomers to an industry. It was quite the opposite. All we wanted to do was to point out the care that should be taken when we give a large scale operation to a newcomer to an industry. I see that the Menzies committee agrees with us. The point is made at page 5 of the report that people awarding tenders should ensure that public money is spent effectively and economically. That is explained at page 8 as follows:
. . . it is essential that officers acquire information as to price, quality and intending contractors' past and likely future performance sufficient to allow sound decisions to be made.

That means that one has to make some assessment of the experience of the contractor to whom one intends to give the job. If the Minister had not understood that that is what page 8 of the Menzies report meant, he could have looked at paragraph 2.22 at page 9 which states:

In assessing tenders for service contracts of the coastwatch type and thus preparing for the exercise of due economy in accordance with Finance Regulation 93, consideration and due weight needs to be given not only to the price offered, but also to the tenderer's capacity, bona fides and past performance.

I will hammer that point because it seems, even in Question Time today, that the Minister still does not appreciate the point we are making. It was not that just because one does not have experience one could not get a contract; it was that lack of experience should put a tender board or tender assessment committee on clear notice. If the Minister turns to page 10, he will see that there is a difference between awarding a contract for goods and awarding a contract for services. The Menzies report states:
This requires risk analysis of the offer-a rigorous evaluation of capacity, competence and capability of the tenderer, having regard to the technical, managerial and financial matters.

The responsibility here falls to the decision-maker. The Minister has tried to tell us today that someone else made the decision-not the relevant Minister, but someone else. Surely the Minister is responsible for allowing someone else to make the decision. If the Minister still has not caught on, I draw his attention to page 33 of the report. It appears that while members of the Government have not accepted this point, the departmental working party did so. Under the heading `Observations and Comments', paragraph 2 says:

The Departmental Working Party alerted the Tender Assessment Committee members to the need to take into account a company's capacity to perform for the life of the contract and that the selection of the cheapest option may not give this assurance.

Yet long after this notice was given to the Tender Assessment Committee, we heard from Government Ministers and members that they were saving government money by awarding the contract to the lowest price tenderer. The Menzies report harps on this point because it obviously sees it as one of the central elements of ineptitude and bungling by the Government-that it did not understand the particular point it wanted to make. I again draw the Minister's attention to page 47 of the Menzies report which states:
According to the records of the Department of Aviation, a finance company was registered as the owner of this aircraft . . .
It further states:
. . . Amann could not have engaged in any form of commercial aviation operation . . .
that is, prior to being awarded this contract. Further on page 47 it states:
He-
that is, Amann-
had put forward a proposed structure and organisation for that company-
this was a shelf company acquired in January of this year-
but, at that date, he had no organisation in place.

It is unbelievable that the Government and the Tender Assessment Committee had all these opportunities to hear bells ringing to warn them to take extra care. On page 48 we see the attitude of the Tender Assessment Committee Chairman which, as I understand it, is roughly the Minister's attitude. The Chairman said:
. . . there is nothing to indicate that he-
that is, Amann-
will not be able to do it . . .

That begs the question of whether the Tender Assessment Committee, the Minister and senior public servants involved bothered to look for anything that would indicate that he would not be able to do it. It is simply not good enough just to say, `This is a new person in the business but I will not hold that against him'. The Government should be saying, `I won't hold that against him but how will he acquire the experience, expertise and managerial competence to enable him to simply proceed with this contract?'. If I understand the Minister's answers in Question Time, that is what he is saying to us today. He is saying that, because nothing jumps out as a problem, a $17m contract can be awarded-jump right in, throw caution to the wind, do not make the relevant inquiries that a Minister ought to make and all will be well. If it proves to be a massive fiasco and bungle, the Government can claim that it has not lost any money, despite the fact that there has been a significant expense outlaid in sorting out just how big this bungle really is.
Finally, the conclusion drawn by the committee that brings together all these points that I have been making is on page 49, listed as paragraph 4. The committee says-and these are not my words:

Given that the T.A.C. knew of Amann's lack of experience, absence of organization and having no aircraft for use under the contract, the T.A.C., if it were minded, in spite of these matters, to consider seriously his tender-
I emphasise the words `if it were minded, in spite of these matters, to consider seriously his tender'-
should have submitted his costings to a particularly rigorous and competent examination. In the event this was not done.
Is the Minister telling us that, because that kind of incompetence has been engaged in, no one is responsible? This is outrageous.

There are many more examples. In the limited time remaining to me I will draw the attention of honourable senators to some of them. It is quite clear from this report that the Department, I think it was the Department of Transport, knew in early 1985 of the difficulties that would be encountered in reletting the coast- watch contract. Yet it was August 1986, nearly two years later, before it was proceeding to develop tender documents. That in itself should have put one of the Ministers responsible at the time on notice that things were not working properly or efficiently, that things were not being done as they should.

The report shows further that the Tender Assessment Committee squashed into three months an evaluation that normally takes six months. It squashed the period for the evaluation of a contract worth $17m into just half the normal time. As if that were not enough, the three months that the Committee did allow for a job that would normally take six months was to be undertaken over the Christmas break so most of the suitable staff were not available. But there has been more incompetence and more bungling. The Menzies report makes it quite clear that the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) gave quite deficient advice about the tender documents to the relevant departments. In particular, if the Minister cares to turn his attention to page 27 of the report he will see the following:
However, it could not be said to be clearly a responsibility of the A.G.S., as circumstances then stood, to point out such a matter which should have been recognised by the client Department.

It is not clearly the responsibility of the Government Solicitor, but the implication is that perhaps the AGS ought to have bothered. In any event, as this report says, if the Government Solicitor is cleared from responsibility for not having pointed out the very important aspect of having progressive start-up dates included in the contract, the need for that should most certainly have been recognised by the client department. The Minister cannot have it both ways. If the Government Solicitor is to be cleared, we have to blame the client department which did not see the need through its own eyes. If the Minister turns to page 52 of the report he will see more examples of bungling. I say for those who have not run their eyes over the 60-page report that this paragraph is particularly damning. It states:
The Notice of Acceptance-
that is, of the tender-
did not include in the letters incorporated in the contract a letter dated 12 January 1987 from Amann which offered progressive start-up dates for different bases.

In other words, the Department was offered progressive start-up dates. It was given the opportunity of including them in the contract but simply ignored it. Again on page 52 of the report, the Committee stated:
The A.G.S. should have drawn to the attention of D.O.T. the possible course of incorporating as terms of the contract the progressive start-up dates offered in Amann's letter of 12 January . . .

Incidentally, a couple of the letters were lost, which might account for a further aspect of the bungling. There has been further bungling. The departmental estimates of costs, what the tenders would be, apparently were significantly higher than those supplied by the successful tenderer. Now, for example, if I were expecting to buy a kilogram of apples for $4 and someone offered them for $2, I would pick up the apples and have a pretty good look at them. I would have thought that the Department would have undertaken that kind of simple observation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister should have done it too.

—Certainly, the Department should have undertaken that investigation as a consequence of instructions from the Minister. There has been further bungling. The Department accepted a number of tenders that, strictly speaking, could have been regarded as informal. Those tenders were faxed to it at the last minute. I would not buy a dog from someone who offered me a contract at the last minute before I closed tenders, let alone let out a $17m contract for the surveillance of the northern coastline of this country. It is absolutely unbelievable that that is what the Department did. The details are clearly laid out on pages 30 and 31 of the report. The Department apparently ignored discrepancies in various financial statements supplied by Amann. Far from being on notice that these people were inexperienced and ought to be watched more carefully, the Department was actually given discrepant financial statements and did not appear to take too much notice of that. It accepted blindly, where the contractor had managerial deficiencies, his offer, as a way of getting over that, to hire people in. Does that mean that, if I want to set up an entertainment company, I can become an Edgley tomorrow because, where I do not have the experience, I can give an undertaking to hire it in? It is patently ludicrous for a department so incompetently to accept this. There was inadequate recording of the Department's views and record keeping. The request to change aircraft, agreed by the Menzies report, was a very lightly considered request and may have provided the opportunity for the Government to get out of this. The Government was aware that the principal was on shoddy ground-in the Governments words, `unaware of the dimensions of the task'-and still publicly, in Estimates hearings and in the Senate from the beginning of this matter being raised, spoke confidently about the contractor's capacity to carry out this task. That is what Senator Evans has to do. He has to tell us why, when the Government has been on notice so long, it has consistently presented to this chamber a scenario that all was well, that nothing was wrong and the coastwatch contract would be properly carried out by Amann Aviation. I defy him to do it successfully because he will not be able to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The awarding of the coastwatch contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd and the handling of that whole affair was unquestionably an administrative exercise that went wrong. It did not go disastrously wrong in the sense that lives were lost or anyone was injured as a result. It did not go disastrously wrong in the sense that hundreds of millions of dollars were lost from the public accounts, as occurred with the bottom of the drawer tax disaster perpetrated by Senator Durack, Mr Howard and others in the previous Government. It did not go wrong even in the sense that there was any loss of continuity in coastal surveillance of our northern coastline. Not a single day's flying was lost as a result of any of the things that did go administratively wrong in this whole affair. It did certainly go wrong in the sense that an organisation which was the lowest conforming tenderer was, nonetheless, clearly ill-equipped to do the job, despite some heroic efforts on its behalf to meet the deadline to match the performance criteria and was an organisation that had to have its contract terminated. That, in turn, has led to a very significant investment of time, energy and resources to establishing a continuing interim arrangement and, of course, to setting in train a new tender process.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that something did go wrong administratively has never been denied by me. I have been publicly quite explicit on the subject since it became apparent that the contract was clearly not going to be met. Up until then in my case, as with the previous spokesmen in this chamber and as indeed was the case with Mr Morris, a degree of discretion had to be exercised in the way the matter was handled publicly because of the intricacies of the operation of the law of contract and the very real difficulty that stood in the way whatever the mounting fears there may have been that the contract would not be met and the very real fears that existed as to the legal impossibility of terminating that contract before the due date.

There has been no attempt by anyone, certainly not by me, to cover this matter up in any way. At the time of the termination of the contract I gave a very full explanation as to the entire set of circumstances, supported by a very full internal report by the Associate Secretary of my Department, Mr Beale, who I had tasked for that particular purpose. At the same time, I set in train a full external review of the whole affair in order that we might derive the appropriate lessons from it and it is that review that is the subject of these Opposition fulminations today, the review that resulted in the interim report put down very swiftly at the beginning of October with its recommendations about the future conduct of the tender process and the final report which has just been put down now, in mid-November, just a few weeks later again which deals, of course, with the circumstances of what actually happened and the lessons that can be learned from it so far as the quality of administrative performance and the future are concerned.

I am very interested to see that there has been no attack or assault on the integrity or bona fides of that particular group that I put together for this purpose, nor should there be. Mr Andrew Menzies, OBE, the chairman of it, is one of the most competent, distinguished and universally respected public servants that it has been my privilege to know. I know that Senator Durack would certainly confirm that from his personal experience as Attorney-General. We have Mr Stan Perry, Assistant Secretary from the Department of Administrative Services Purchasing Policy Branch and an acknowledged expert in contracting matters, and Mr Barry Slingo, an Assistant Secretary in the Department of Defence, presently acting as manager of defence contracts in the regional office in Victoria with both engineering qualifications and outstanding personal experience and reputation in this whole tendering area. So a highly qualified and credible group has been put together and I accept in every respect the findings and the recommendations that it has made about the way in which we should act in the future as far as these matters are concerned.

The findings are extensive. I will not track over them as Senator Vanstone has done, with lots of sound and appropriate fury, as we might have expected on this occasion. I do not disagree with her characterisation of the things that went wrong. I suppose that they can be summarised quite briskly by saying, as I did pretty much in these terms at the time of initially explaining why the contract was not being pursued, that there were cumulative inadequacies in the tender evaluation arising from an incomplete understanding of contractual policy, misunderstandings between departments and pressure to meet shortened deadlines during a period of staff absences and disruption. All those things are true and the criticism that flows from that, both in general terms and as to chapter and verse in a number of instances, I believe are thoroughly justified and I do not seek in any way to resile from that.

The particular point that I make relates to the performance of the Ministers involved in this affair because necessarily any response to a matter of this kind raises questions of ministerial responsibility. They have been at the forefront of the assault-if it can be so regarded-mounted today, both in Question Time and in the speech we have just heard from Senator Vanstone, and they are matters which quite naturally come to mind in dealing with circumstances of this kind. But to the extent that there may have been any ground for concern from late March onwards so far as the knowledge of particular Ministers was concerned-there was such a ground from late March when, as the report makes clear, the report of the regional director in New South Wales came to the attention of Minister Morris and he reacted accordingly, as did everyone else, with some concern-the point about all the knowledge that existed at that stage was that it was after the contract was awarded rather than before. As I have constantly made the point-and there is nothing in the Menzies Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract report to countermand it-whatever the degree of concern that might have existed after the contract was awarded, it was not concern that could be realised in terms of action taken to terminate the contract simply because the legal grounds were not there to do so.

That such legal grounds were not there I acknowledge certainly may have had something to do with the way in which the contract was formulated with its absence of phase-in times and hurdle points along the way that could have triggered remedial action. That did not happen. The fact that it was not possible for such remedial action to be taken reflects another failing in this whole administrative process and one that will be corrected for the future. But to the extent that criticisms have been made of ministerial inaction after the awarding of the contract, for the reasons I have just indicated there cannot possibly be any foundation for any such claim and I do not think any such claim is really seriously made. Most of the claims go back to the circumstances as they existed before the final granting of the contract on 12 March this year.

In respect of those circumstances, the report-which is not challenged as to the bona fides of its authors and is not challenged as to any chapter and verse in it-is very full indeed in describing the state of knowledge of the relevant Ministers at this time, in describing the kind of information they had before them and in describing the impossibility, as a result of the paucity of information before them, of their being in a reasonable position to respond adversely to the situation as they found it.

Two particular circumstances were the subject of very full discussion on pages 56 to 59 of this report. The first was the circumstances leading up to the endorsement by Cabinet on 2 March of the submission providing authority for the funding of the contract. The second set of circumstances lies behind the submission to the Acting Minister, which was endorsed by him on 9 March, actually finally approving the contract. So far as the former set of circumstances is concerned, the report makes it clear that the Minister at the time was simply not alerted to a concern which existed within the Department of Aviation suggesting that there was an element of risk `albeit small that Mr Amann will experience difficulties in obtaining the necessary air service licence'.

That language which appeared in a co-ordinating comment from the Department of Aviation was not, through a chain of circumstances which are here fully described, drawn to Minister Morris's attention before he went overseas; it was not drawn to the attention of the Acting Minister, Mr Scholes, in the minute that ended up on his desk; and it was not drawn to the attention of Mr Duffy, who acted for Mr Scholes in the Cabinet because Mr Scholes was ill on the day in question. So the one piece of information that could have alerted any of these Ministers to the existence of a risk factor, an element of possible anxiety, simply was not there.

Similarly, when it came to the formal endorsement of the contract and the submission that was put to Acting Minister Scholes and endorsed by him on 9 March, there was nothing in any of the documentation put to the Minister by his Department, acting on the advice of the Tender Assessment Committee constructed specifically for that purpose-to do these things at arm's length-which could possibly have alerted him to that situation. I read again the relevant passage from page 59 of the Menzies report:

The submission to the Minister should have disclosed that Amann had limited experience in the aviation industry, he did not have an organisation in existence and, while he stated that he had made arrangements to acquire the necessary aircraft from overseas, he did not at that date own any of the required aircraft. The information in fact provided including the information provided to the Minister a few days earlier in relation to the Cabinet Submission was insufficient to alert the Minister to any of these matters nor, of course, to the unreliability of the costings investigation.

So that is the situation so far as the Ministers are concerned. All that one is left with is some sort of extremely generalised assertion that the Minister of the day should have been somehow aware that there was a series of failings and inadequacies in the way in which the tender from Amann had been evaluated; that he should have drawn all sorts of adverse conclusions based simply on such knowledge, very limited as it was, about the very small scale of this organisation and should have acted somehow to stop the whole previously running independent evaluation process going ahead. There is simply no basis for any such assertion, if it is to be made-and it was not made with any clarity by Senator Vanstone-and if that is what the Opposition believes. As a result, there cannot possibly be any ground for an assertion of individual ministerial failing, so far as the time leading up to the granting of the contract is concerned. I have already dealt with the circumstances of the time after the granting of the contract. The whole question of individual ministerial responsibility has been the subject of an enormous amount of humbug perpetrated by parties in opposition over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you in opposition.
—Come on, we don't want humbug in this instance.
—What a short memory some people have.

—If Senator Walters, Senator Durack and Senator Stone are responding to my suggestion of humbuggery by claiming that something of an untoward kind has happened when the Australian Labor Party has been in opposition, I am prepared to take that on board on the basis that they accept that these days there is no foundation whatsoever for any claim for resignation on the ground of individual ministerial responsibility. They cannot have it both ways. I do not propose to have it both ways. I have not had it both ways since we have been in government. I have had a very single-minded view of what individual ministerial responsibility means. That is endorsed by what was said by Mr Reid, another distinguished public servant, when he reported on this matter in the following terms in 1983 in his Review of Commonwealth Administration:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, we shall try to dispose of one myth. When ministerial responsibility is discussed in Australia, many assert that in the United Kingdom ministers automatically, regularly, or often resign where there are acts of maladministration by their departments, allegedly amounting to a convention of resignation.

This is a fallacy. As Appendix 8 demonstrates, this has never really been a convention in the UK. Indeed, we have not been able to identify (in well over 100 years) a single case that can properly and confidently be claimed as a resignation for that reason.

It is interesting that even the 1954 Crichel Down case, involving the resignation of Sir John Dugdale, which I have always regarded as an example of just that instance, is not so regarded by Mr Reid on the basis of the analysis he makes of that case. He goes on to say:

Ministers-in Australia as well as the United Kingdom-have of course profferred resignations for a wide range of reasons, such as personal actions or indiscretions, misleading of the Parliament, policy failures, policy differences with colleagues, and so on. But they raise quite different issues from the handling of cases of maladministration by a department.
That is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes you a humbug.

—I do not wish to hear any more humbug from Senator Durack, given his failure to resign after the extraordinary and grotesque exercise in maladministration by him as Attorney-General in association with Mr Howard as Treasurer in regard to the bottom of the harbour tax cases. To hear any suggestions from either of those gentlemen that there is something wrong with the propositions I am espousing today amounts to breathtaking hypocrisy. I am glad that they have now been silenced on the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to the question of the appropriate administrative response to the administrative failings that have here been described. I have made it clear that there can be no question, in principle or on the basis of the facts before us, of any ministerial responsibility being taken to the extent of some discipline being imposed on Ministers, for reasons I have just expressed. But the question arises as to what action should be taken in relation to the departmental officials concerned. I make the point, only in passing, that there is no explicit recommendation on the subject of disciplinary action so far as the Menzies report is concerned. Perhaps that is not surprising as the terms of reference were inexplicit, as Senator Vanstone said, on that subject.

But I certainly regard it as my responsibility to look at the question of disciplinary action in the light of the report and in the light of my understanding of all the events. I have looked at that question very carefully. I have reached a view which I have indicated publicly and which I will restate now. It is true that the report is critical, in particular, of the performance of the present Director of Supply and Services on a number of dimensions relating to his conduct of the tender processes. The report also concludes that senior management of the then Department did not exercise sufficient supervision of the matter and were aware of the limits of the Director's expertise and should have raised the question of whether the services of a specialist financial investigator should have been obtained.

I simply make the point now that I am satisfied, after reading the report and taking advice on this matter from other areas within my Department, that the Director of Supply and Services did not lack personal effort or diligence in his handling of this matter. Rather, what he lacked was experience and professional development in the complexities of administering a major contract. Accordingly, it has not been recommended to me that any disciplinary action be taken against him and I have taken the strong view that disciplinary action, for that reason and a number of other reasons which I will not go into now, would be inappropriate in all the circumstances of this case. Nonetheless, if and when he recovers from the very serious illness which he presently has and which was the subject of some very untoward guffaws from the Opposition in Question Time today, he will be counselled in accordance with the recommendations of the report. Arrangements will be made for appropriate skill development training in the event that he happens to be involved in contract assessments of this type in the future.

Similarly, the senior managers, such of them as are still there in line positions in the Department, that had broad responsibility for the contract will be strongly counselled-I emphasise `strongly'-on their responsibility to assess carefully the skills of the officers who are assigned to carrying out these sorts of contract tasks. Arrangements will be made for their supplementation as necessary and to closely track and supervise the processes. The Associate Secretary of my Department, Mr Beale, who is a newcomer to the Department and was not involved in any way in these matters at the time, will personally interview each of the key officers whose performance was questioned under the contract. It will not be a punitive process. It will be aimed at coolly exploring the facts with each officer, and the reasons for any failures and how those are best addressed, leading, we hope, to agreement on a personal development program if appropriate.

These are highly sensitive personnel matters. It would be inappropriate to go further into individual circumstances or to huff and puff and rage about disciplinary action and so on of the kind that we heard, not so much from Senator Vanstone, I acknowledge, in her speech, but certainly in Question Time today. I repeat: I make no bones at all about accepting that this was a very significant administrative foul-up. There is no other way of describing it. It is explicable by reference to a major league matter, as I said in Question Time, perhaps being dealt with in a way that it should not have been by minor league players. The Department essentially was inexperienced in handling major contract matters, particularly those for the supply of services. From the things that went wrong we have learned a great deal, as I hope all government administrations learn from such things. In those circumstances, I do not believe that this motion is remotely justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I support the urgency motion moved by the Opposition which I will not read in full but which reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to accept responsibility at both political and bureaucratic level for the gross mismanagement . . . in . . . the Coastwatch contract fiasco . . .

I was rather relieved today to see Senator Evans, probably for the first time, acknowledge that there had been deficiencies in the awarding of this contract. The sad reality of this is that through the inadequacies of the Department of Transport and Communications people could have died because what he was putting at risk and what his former ministerial colleagues were putting at risk was the surveillance of the northern coastline of this country. If foot and mouth disease had entered this country, if we had had drug runners, gun runners or whatever operating as a result, it could have ended with people dying.

I was absolutely astonished that Senator Evans also said that there was no loss of continuity. There was no loss of continuity by very, very good luck, rather than good management. I cannot for the life of me understand how any person can claim that this is a matter of urgency--
This, as I said, was when we were debating the coastwatch situation way back on 13 May. He went on to say:
and of such importance as to justify spending two hours debating the acceptance by the Government of a contract dealing with the surveillance of our coastline.

Senator Gietzelt, the Minister then responsible in this chamber, did not see it as an important issue. That in itself was a disgrace. He went on to say, on that particular day, that what we-that is, the Opposition-were trying to do was:
to upset a legitimate and properly conducted public tender process . . .

We have seen from the Menzies report on the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract that it has been anything but that. He also said that he was simply trying to `save the public dollar'. Surely the Government and all its Ministers have a responsibility to make sure that in saving a public dollar the country and particularly its coastline are not put at risk. Senator Gietzelt claimed that the whole debate was nonsense. Once again, the word `nonsense' comes from his speech to the Parliament that day. Once again I quote Senator Gietzelt's words:
There is a need for protection of our country from agricultural diseases, illegal immigration, illegal fishing, drug running and . . . other matters . . .

Yet he did not consider that the fiasco that was obviously apparent at that stage was important enough to take on board. Senator Gietzelt could not even answer questions in the Senate on this matter. He said, `I do not have a brief on this'. That was about three, four or five weeks after questioning had actually started; yet he had not considered the matter important enough even to have a brief on it. He went on to say:
. . . it is the cheapest and most dubious of all tactics to suggest that the Government has acted improperly.

What we were saying is that there were deficiencies in the Department, there were deficiencies in the administration by the Minister, and yet he was prepared to whitewash the whole thing and put it to bed as such. Later on that day we heard from Senator Reynolds, who has now been miraculously promoted as a Minister in this place. In respect of comments from Senator Vanstone, Senator Reynolds had the audacity to say-I quote from her speech that day:
I wonder why Senator Vanstone is so concerned about this particular issue. I doubt if there is very much northern coastline surveillance needed from the leafy suburbs of Adelaide.

How outrageous it is for Senator Reynolds-now meant to be a Minister of the Crown and a senator for Queensland, which has a very large coastline-to say that another senator, Senator Vanstone, should not be concerned about coastal surveillance purely and simply because she comes from South Australia. That is absolutely ridiculous. Senator Reynolds went on to say in her outrageous speech that day:
The aircraft will have the same surveillance capability as the present aircraft. . .

At that stage she was referring to the change of aircraft that Amann had sought. That was not so. As we found out when the planes eventually arrived in Australia, they were not equipped as they were meant to be: they did not have the long range fuel tanks; they did not have bubble windows; they did not have dropping facilities; and they were not here when the Government told us they would be. Senator Reynolds also went on to say that the whole debate that day was trivial. We do not believe that it was trivial that day and we do not believe that it is trivial now. What we need to consider is the fact that the Government and its Ministers are responsible and should stand condemned for the total incompetence in handling this entire coastwatch contract.

Their incompetence is now simply a matter of fact, and we all know that. The blatantly false information supplied to the Parliament, the Senate in particular, is an absolute disgrace. I will give a further example. Senator Gietzelt, who, as I said before, was then the Minister responsible in this place, as far back as 18 March, in answer to a question by Senator Durack, said that proper tendering procedures had been carried out. That is an absolute joke because, according to the Menzies report, which we have now seen, that is clearly not so. But Senator Gietzelt would not have known what time of day it was, let alone whether the correct tendering procedures had taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he today?

—Where is he today? He sat here for a couple of minutes while Senator Vanstone was talking. That was it; he shot through. He was not interested at the time; he is not interested now; and he could not care less about the surveillance of the coastline. On 30 March, Senator Tate told the Senate that he understood there would be a staged takeover, base by base. There was clearly no such arrangement. It is all very well for the Government to say that it was cutting costs by accepting the lowest tender, but why cut the surveillance throat in the process? Why put at risk the whole security of the northern Australian coastline?

SPEECH.PARA: Any government is obliged to choose the most technically competent tenderer as well as the cheapest. This Government did not do so on this occasion. Senator Gietzelt's inadequacy in handling the issue-I will go so far as to say-was almost unequalled in disgrace. On 4 May, in answer to one of my questions on this matter, he just said, `No brief, no brief'. This was said on 4 May, yet this matter had been debated since March. How incompetent can one get? The Government's incompetence has resulted in individuals suffering huge losses, both financial and personal. In no way have we ever tried to attack Amann Aviation Pty Ltd or support another tenderer. We have simply said, `Let us have the most competent operator that we can possibly have'. Quite frankly, I feel very sorry that Amann, through the Government's inadequacies and mismanagement, has in fact suffered the losses that it has recently suffered.

Of course, we have not heard anything about compensation. We just hear the Minister continue saying, `There have been no additional costs'. How can there be no additional costs when the Skywest contract has been extended? I know for a fact that the Skywest contract did have a surcharge and a penalty rate on it. Yet we have repeatedly heard the Minister say, `There was no such penalty'. We know that the cost of the inquiries is enormous. We know that the cost of Senate committees sitting is enormous as well. Skywest has in fact said in a letter to the Minister that it had applied for escalation of the rates under its current contract and would continue to do so through to the deadline that it had at this stage. We must look at some of the losses and the effects of this in the total system. On page 11, the Menzies report states:

It is essential that, before accepting confirmation of the tendered price, the responsible contracts officer be satisfied that the tenderer fully appreciated the obligation to comply strictly with the required specification and is aware of the conditions that apply should default occur.

Obviously, the Department did not know and the Minister did not know. Of course, Senator Evans admitted today what is also in the Menzies report-that we had the Minister represented by a Minister who was represented at a Cabinet meeting by a Minister who was not even briefed. That was the basis on which the decision was made. Mr Morris was then the Minister and Mr Scholes was unable to represent him because of illness, so Mr Duffy represented him. The Minister representing the Minister representing the Minister then did not have any oral briefing but found it okay to make a decision. It is absolutely unbelievable to think that a government can award a $17m contract without any formal briefing.

The Department of Transport tender document was deficient in a number of areas. The Menzies report says that maybe those deficiencies were not sufficient to cause real problems. But when we go through the list of deficiencies it is obvious that they would have made it very difficult for tenderers to fill out the form accurately and for the decisions to be made accurately. The Department of Transport lost even more time during the tender process because of the involvement of so many departments trying to argue about requirements. There were so many basic faults in the tender document; the list just goes on and on.

At the end of the report there are 16 findings on how this thing was mucked up right from the word go. It refers to the Department's handling of experienced staff who were already on Skywest's payroll. Their representations were ignored and Senator Evans has not even had the courtesy to reply to the representations from those staff that he received in his office. I found it quite amazing that today Senator Vallentine got up and talked about the coastwatch contract. She did not take any interest in that in respect of her State before, but she has come to life today.

The Minister responsible should be sacked; there is no doubt about that. Senator Gietzelt has already gone out of the window, and I suppose that is the best thing that could have happened to the Parliament. The problem is that this was a case of gross mismanagement by the Government. Ministers, including Senator Evans, would not respond to questions that were raised in this place. That has been an absolute disgrace to the Parliament and to the people of Australia. The attitude taken by this Government on such an important issue has been less than careful. We must remember that so much has gone into this Menzies report. I hope, in line with a question asked by Senator Durack today of Senator Foreman, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure, which is looking into this matter, that the Committee will abide by the guidelines set down by the Senate for investigating this matter. They have to be far wider than those laid down for the Menzies inquiry. I am sure that we will find many more skeletons falling out of the cupboard before the day's end.

In passing I touch on the security of the coastline which I mentioned earlier when debating this matter. Great misconceptions are attached to what flights along the northern coast of Australia are for and what they accomplish. Anyone who has had any close association with how this surveillance operates and has watched it in action could be quickly disabused of the fact that Australia's national security is at risk. I mention that matter simply because that misapprehension about the purpose of these flights comes up again and again. The reality is, apart from the fiction the Opposition would like to create on this matter, that flights were never discontinued or placed at risk.

Therefore it is mainly a question of examining-material is now available in the public arena-the matters touched on by the report. I will not waste the time of the Senate in doing so. We have more than enough business to deal with by the end of this year without sitting any more days than are now scheduled. The details of this report have been gone over by, I think, three speakers in this debate and the honourable senator who moved the motion. The findings that have been made by those investigating the matter have, as I have said, been largely in accordance with the information that was contained in the interim report and discussed at length in the Senate.

Two major findings, Nos 4 and 6, are relevant to the serious bungles and are contained on pages 70 and 71 of the report. Finding No. 4 lists the major deficiencies of the Amann company. I will read finding (6) to the Senate because I think it is important in relation to the catcalls, interjections and cries for blood which came from those opposite this morning and which Senator Gareth Evans and I found distasteful. This report quite clearly and correctly points out that despite the catalogue of problems-I add that they were not confined to the Department of Transport; the report makes that clear too-that occurred during this contract, the two key things that went wrong in respect of remedying the problems were contained in the two findings (4) and (6). Those two sections are important and reference to them is important because one must then turn to finding (12) on page 73, which states:

(12) Information put before Ministers in relation to the Cabinet Submission seeking funds authorization and the submission seeking authority under regulation 48 (c) of the Finance Regulations to enter into the contract with Amann did not reveal either the facts set out in (4) or the unreliability of the financial investigation described in (6).

They were absolutely crucial omissions. The Minister has already touched upon the myth and nonsense that surrounds the so-called doctrine of the Westminster system of responsibility. It is a matter that has reared its head again and again. I was a member of the Northern Territory Parliament where I have made the point before that the conservative Chief Minister of the time instituted various reforms to the Public Service administration in the Territory. I did not realise that the question of responsibility extended downwards from the Government into the Public Service as well as upwards. It is a new concept for me. There were always two institutions as far as I was aware and they were the Government and the Public Service and that is the way it should be. The question of Ministers being expected to resign over some piece of administration which does not directly involve them in impropriety or incompetence is now so much a question of flogging a dead horse that I am surprised it is even raised in an Australian parliament these days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose responsibility is it if it is not the Minister's?

—Who is responsible?

—I refer again to the crucial aspects of this matter. It is not a particularly edifying matter as I am the first to admit with some degree of heat and anger, as someone who is interested in competent administration. If the honourable senator would refer to findings (4), (6) and (12) she will come part way to answering that question.

SPEECH.PARA: Someone spoke this morning about people refusing to accept responsibility. As I have said, I have been in the Senate only a short time but there have been previous debates in this chamber on this same matter and we are going over the same ground again today. Who could presume to do anything else in the face of the findings of this report?

There is no need for me to repeat that because it is clearly documented in the report. I am not quite sure, as a result of the catcalls, interjections and statements that were made in Question Time today, what people could expect from the Opposition in government or how far the Opposition expects the Government to go. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The mismanagement of the contract for the coastwatch surveillance is a classic example of the way in which this Government's defence and securities priorities are askew. This and previous governments' priorities seem to lie in spending taxpayers' money on buying expensive, high-tech equipment from the United States, like the FA18, to meet a non-existent threat. In turn this causes our neighbours to buy similar expensive planes. What we should be doing instead is making light aircraft here in Australia to patrol our coastlines looking for real threats to our security-illegal immigration, drug smuggling, private arms dealing to people like the white settlers in Kanaky or New Caledonia, the poaching of maritime resources and the dangers of bringing in infected or contaminated agricultural products or plants.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that even someone with the nom de plume of `Cyclops' has written an article in the journal of the Australian Naval Institute for August this year criticising the FA18 purchase if the real threat is from small boatloads of guerrillas. What is needed are the now discarded Navy Trackers and Skyhawks which would have been not only adequate but cheaper by a factor of 10 times at least. I would go further and suggest that instead of spending $30m apiece on the FA18s we should develop a strategy of defensive defence and build light aircraft in Australia for coastal patrols, preferably to come under the coastguard service. The cost of one FA18 is almost double the cost of the entire coastwatch service over a three-year program.

The current confusion over the coastwatch program appears to have been caused by the Government's refusal to budget adequately for this service and the low priority it gives to this kind of security, preferring to tailor our defence purchases to the needs of the United States and to pay millions of dollars for exercises and patrols in the North Pacific, well outside our zone of interest, as defined by the White Paper. I am even more perplexed by the demands of some people in the defence community and their supporters here in this Parliament who want to buy nuclear submarines, and who, if they agree with Peter Young's latest column in the Australian this week, would invest in three aircraft carriers for the Royal Australian Navy. I often wonder how they propose to pay for these items and what effect they would have on our balance of payments.

The current Government-and presumably its predecessor, if it accepted the findings of the 1981 Katter report entitled Threats to Australia's Security-considers that there is no invasion threat to Australia in the foreseeable future and that no country apart from the United States and the Soviet Union could successfully invade Australia anyway.

So why do we have to spend over $4 billion in the United States on the FA18 program instead of making planes here in Australia to patrol our coasts to deal with day to day threats? The coastwatch patrol fulfils a vital day to day function that we have skimped on for many years because of our national obsession with the threat from the north while ignoring the kinds of threats to our security with which the coastwatch patrol is supposed to deal. It is this distortion of priorities that lies behind the confusion over this contract and I hope that this perspective will not be lost sight of when we deal with this motion which is essentially an exercise to embarrass the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this urgency motion concerning the coastwatch contract. We feel that this shonky Government deserves to have its wrists slapped because yet again it has tried to operate on the cheap. It does not really know what it is doing in this tendering process. I will expand on that. This time the Government got its hand caught in the cookie jar over its handling of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd tender. A number of honourable senators have referred to the final report of the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract. I do not want to belabour this point, but on page 49, under the heading `Conclusions', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the TAC knew of Amann's lack of experience, absence of organization and having no aircraft for use under the contract, the TAC, if it were minded, in spite of these matters, to consider seriously his tender, should have submitted his costings to a particularly rigorous and competent examination. In the event this was not done.
It is stated on page 70, in the findings section of the report:
No evidence was found indicating corruption or other illegal conduct by any officer of the Commonwealth.

There was just bureaucratic stupidity. I will not repeat what Senator Collins has said, on this section, but I do point out that the Department of Aviation came under some scrutiny, and well it might have. The report says, on page 73:
There was confusion between DOT and DOA-
the Department of Transport and the Department of Aviation-

as to the role of the representative of the latter Department on the TAC. This caused the Chairman of the TAC to assume that this representative would provide input or advice on any matter within the general responsibility of the latter Department-
that is, the Department of Aviation-

whereas the representative's instructions from his Department were to confine his role to advice on technical matters such as compliance with legislation administered by his Department. Such confusion would not have arisen if the roles of representatives had been appropriately defined in advance.

I urge the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, who is in the chamber, to heed those words about the Department of Aviation, now part of the Department of Transport and Communications-which is his responsibility.

I refer to a document entitled No Port in a Storm. It is a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure on the Darling Harbour fiasco-and the words `Darling Harbour fiasco' are in the title of the document. I think the Committee received 700 written submissions, instituted by Dick Smith, from pilots and operators in Australia, and the conclusion it came to was that the Department of Aviation was indeed in a shambles as far as its operations and internal communications were concerned. The Committee's first recommendation states:
. . . that the administrative arrangements be reviewed by the Department of Aviation within the framework of its existing administrative structure.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The visitors will be removed from the gallery.

—I think this interruption, although unparliamentary, illustrates the depth of feeling in the Aboriginal community over the deaths in Australian prison cells. I think this is a problem that we should be addressing.
—Against a bloody dreadful Government, too.

—As Senator Chaney says, against a bloody dreadful Government. I do not know whether that is parliamentary language, but what we saw shows the depth of feeling in the country which should be listened to.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to the rather mundane situation at hand. Perhaps this matter is not mundane; perhaps it relates to what we have just seen. The disinterest by the Government in the amount of taxpayers' money that has been spent in the tendering process is similar to the disinterest that the Government shows in the welfare of the Aboriginal people. I was pointing out that the then Department of Aviation had its own communications problems internally and with other organisations. In the case of Amann Aviation, the Department was found to be derelict in this respect.

This is not the first time that we have had this type of fiasco in the processes of dealing with government products, government property and government money. The Age of 23 October 1987 contained an article on the C130 Hercules aircraft. The headline to the article reads, `Life Aid aircraft at centre of federal fraud inquiry' and it states:
The RAAF Hercules aircraft presented by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to Bob Geldof's Life Aid for Africa campaign is at the centre of a Federal Police fraud investigation.

The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, told Parliament yesterday that the police were investigating alleged theft and fraud arising from the refurbishing and leasing of the aircraft, which was presented to the Red Cross for famine relief in Ethiopia in 1986.

The article goes on to list a number of difficulties. The police were investigating the theft of spare parts and fraud against the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The inquiry extended to a series of failed attempts by the Department of Administrative Services to sell the Royal Australian Air Force's (RAAF) fleet of 12 mothballed Hercules, plus the disappearance of spare parts.

This is a long story which we have discussed before. I have brought it up here because of the similarity between this saga, which has gone on for years, and the Amann saga. Apparently the Government learned absolutely nothing from the non-sale of the C130s. An article in the Times on Sunday of 18 October 1987 under the heading `Canberra sacks second Hercules agent' states:
The Federal Government has sacked the exclusive agent handling the sale of its multi-million-dollar fleet of mothballed RAAF Hercules transport planes.

Military Aircraft Sales (MAS), which had the sole right to find buyers for the aircraft, has been told that the contract has been terminated by the Minister for Administrative Services . . . The reason given was that the company failed to sell any planes and failed to pay $5 million it allegedly owed the Government.
The article continues:
Mr Van Loen-
the principal of Military Aircraft Sales-

said last week that despite Mr West's termination of the MAS contract, his company was continuing to try to sell the planes and was very close to getting a deal for the planes. All that was required was the approval of the US Government, which retains a veto over the sale of US made military equipment.
He blamed the Department of Administrative Services for the delays in getting these so-called end-user approvals.
`They don't know how to do business,' he said. `They don't follow practical procedures.

`We have spent $1.5m getting ready for this, including $800,000 of our own money. We will go bust if the sales do not go through. I have been falsely accused by the Government . . . total incompetence within the Government is what is involved.

I do not hold a case for Military Aircraft Sales, which may have its own difficulties, but, certainly, the Government was no help in this. I have a transcript of the entire Four Corners program of 22 June 1987 which honourable senators may have seen. I will read the synopsis by Andrew Olle, the presenter. He said:

Tonight's story is a scandal, indeed the Federal Government announced on Friday, following a newspaper preview of Peter Couchman's report, that there will be a federal police inquiry into the matter. That smart response stands in stark contrast to the bureaucratic bungling we're about to unfold.
Peter Couchman said:
What followed was a bureaucratic bungle that cost millions of dollars and it raises serious questions about the competence of Australian Governments to handle big business contracts.
At the end, Peter Couchman said:

We've only told part of the story. Somewhere in the bureaucracy there are people who know what really happened and they're not telling. The bureaucracy protects itself but there's a lot to answer for. It's incredible that John Ford was able to get eleven extensions of his contract and that the government was prepared to go on doing business with him. It's incredible that Peter Hocking and Ken Oliver were able to carry on that business and for so long. It's incredible that no tenders were called for such valuable contracts and that performance was never monitored. The history of Australian Government contracting hasn't been a proud one but what we've seen shows a level of incompetence and mismanagement that's unbelievable and a terrible waste of public funds. Surely it's time to take a hard look at the whole system. The Hercules affair, if nothing else, shows that there's something awfully wrong.
Has the Government taken a hard look at the system as a result of all that? Of course it has not. If it had, the whole Amann fiasco would not have blown up.

Another thing bothers me about this whole thing, and that is the type of operation that Australia is trying to run in terms of surveillance. Surveillance in most countries is not put out to the cheapest tenderer. Coastal surveillance in most countries is done by the government of that country itself. I believe that coastal surveillance should be conducted by the military and I believe that it should use aircraft which are suitable for the task.

There is one aircraft which is eminently suitable in a number of ways to the task of coastal surveillance, and that is the Canadair CL215. This aircraft is made in Canada. It could be made here. It could be made under licence at the Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermens Bend and it could provide jobs in Australia. This aircraft has a total endurance of 13.5 hours. It can stay in the air for half a day. It can search for six hours, 740 kilometres from its base. It can search for 2 1/2 hours 1,120 kilometres from its base. And it is not limited to surveillance only. It is a seaplane. It is an amphibian actually, and it can land on water. If it spots something suspicious, it can land and do something about it; or it can rescue people. It is certainly a lot more economical to run than the helicopters which are often used for this purpose. It cruises at 241 kilometres per hour in a search mode, and in a passenger capacity it can carry up to 26 passengers. It is a multi-purpose aircraft.

This is another very attractive aspect of the CL215, because, as honourable senators well know, we have a bushfire problem in Australia. Much of our bush is near water-near the ocean, large lakes or rivers. The CL215 has a capacity to scoop up six tonnes of water while skimming the surface of a water body. It does not have to set down in the water. It can do this in waves up to two metres high. Incidentally, it can land in waves up to four metres high. It is a very versatile aircraft. Whilst some may say that the purchase price of some $12m is high, in its multi-purpose role it would in fact be quite economical. Water bombing as a means of bushfire control is proven around the world. It is certainly very good in subduing a small fire that has just started or in protecting lives or property around habitation areas. It is in use in many parts of the world. It would be a tremendous asset to Australia in its multi-purpose role, whether fire fighting, carrying passengers, in search and rescue, and/or coastal surveillance.

We have covered a number of issues, including governmental bungling and bureaucratic bungling. I hope that both the Government and the bureaucrats have learnt their lesson. I do not know whether my hope is justified, but I think we should demand that the Government make some wise decisions on coastal surveillance and on fire control. I would urge it very strongly to look at the CL215, and I hope it does. If the Government makes some wise decisions, in the future Australia will certainly benefit and that will be a refreshing change.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that we are considering the estimates for the Department of Industrial Relations at this stage has meant that one of my colleagues, Senator Short, has been caught short, so to speak. He wishes to raise many issues as a result of his question which was provided as attachment B to the report of Estimates Committee A. The question he had asked during the Senate Estimates Committee hearing was:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Department or any of its statutory authorities made available or approved any additional grants not included in answers to questions at the May 1987 Senate Estimate hearing, to any trade unions or community groups in 1986-87 and so far this financial year?
If so, in each case:
(a) What is the name of the trade union or community group which received the funds?
(b) What was the amount of the grant?
(c) What was the purpose of the grant?
(d) Under what program was the grant made?
(e) Was there any contribution by the trade union or community group towards the project and what amounts were involved?

This is an interesting matter because Senator Short and I, among other senators and members, have been concerned about the extent to which government funds have been directed towards people in manners that appear to be very political. I am not saying that that is so in each instance, but it is important for the public to be continually aware of the extent to which government funds are being provided to the union movement for one reason or another.

Obviously, some areas of trade union activity are properly funded by the Government. For example, the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA), whose new Canberra premises were officially opened earlier this week, is one such organisation. I believe it is important to continue the sensible arrangement whereby trade union members increase their understanding of and skill in using the procedures which are open to them and the manner in which they should conduct their relations with employers. I think that the Government is doing the right thing in that respect. It was one of the initiatives of the Whitlam Government which I supported. In fact, it was also supported by the Fraser Government, which continued the funding for the organisation. It seems to me that greater knowledge on the part of members of the trade union movement leads to greater responsibility. To that extent, there is benefit all around. While some benefits come from TUTA and while I am pleased that funding for that kind of organisation should have proceeded under both governments and is now proceeding under the Hawke Government, I still think it vital that there be proper scrutiny of all governmental expenditures relating to the funding of the trade union movement.

We must remember that the Australian Labor Party is allegedly the political wing of the labour movement. Thus, any large expenditures by the Labor Party in government on the trade union movement should naturally be subject to the closest possible scrutiny. There should be no suggestion that this information should not be readily available. That is why I regretted that the information requested by Senator Short, which I would have thought the Department would have expected at the time of the Estimates committees, was not provided while those committees were sitting. We did not get this information until well after the committees ceased sitting and, therefore, were not given the opportunity in the Estimates hearings to ask questions about those particular grants, to pursue their merits or otherwise. The answers have since been provided in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A, albeit well after that Committee ceased meeting. I am not certain about the merits of these grants. No doubt Senator Short, who originally asked the question, would have liked the opportunity to pursue the matter with the public servants involved.

This is just another example of an unsatisfactory situation emerging in Senate Estimates committees, where we are not given the opportunity to ask appropriate questions, as has been the practice in the past, without matters such as this being taken on notice. When the answers come back we cannot find out more about them. For example, I would have liked to find out whether the Federated Ironworkers Association, which received a grant of $45,000, received that grant under industrial democracy agreements, and whether it went to the responsible part of the union-the Sydney and Newcastle based elements of it-or to the Port Kembla branch, which has no interest in industrial democracy or democracy of any kind. It certainly has no interest in the steel industry, as we canvassed at some length this morning.

It is interesting to note the information we have received on grants to various unions bodies such as the Victorian Trades Hall Council, $35,000; the Joint Union Advisory Committee (JUAC), $35,000; the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council, $35,000; the Trade Union Community Research Centre Incorporated of Tasmania, $40,000; the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, $37,000; and the trade union postal courses scheme, $32,000. I understand that many trade unions have enormous assets, as I read a report last year outlining the wealth of many of them. From the information provided, I have no idea what proportion this cost subsidisation-in most cases provided by the Federal Government-represents of the total cost of these programs. We are not told this except in the case of the Joint Union Advisory Committee, with the State Energy Commission of Western Australia, where we see that the $35,000 provided by the Federal Government is to be supported by $200,000 from the State Energy Commission of Western Australia to support the JUAC activities during 1987-88. There we have a total of about $235,000 of Australian taxpayers' money being spent on the employment of an industrial democracy officer to facilitate the development of consultative mechanisms within the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia. Quite frankly, it would be appropriate if we had had the opportunity to ask exactly how this very large amount of money was to be spent. We were denied that opportunity as a result of this information not being readily available while the Senate Estimates committees were sitting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government intend to make enquiries into the extent of South African ownership of the two pharmaceutical companies, Alphapharm Pty Ltd and Protea Pharmaceuticals.
(2) Is legislation being considered whereby all overseas companies will be required to give proof of ownership before being allowed to operate in Australia.
(3) Does the Government intend to make enquiries into the extent of South African ownership, through the enterprises of Mr David Tabatznik, in Australian nursing homes and private hospitals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The extent of South African ownership of Alphapharm Pty Ltd was considered on 28 February 1987 by the Inter-Departmental Committee (IDC) on South African Sanctions, which is chaired by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The IDC noted that `on the evidence available, Alphapharm is not a South African majority owned company; however, that if doubts persist on this matter, that Alphapharm be asked to provide a statutory declaration.'

David Leonard Duchen, a director of Alphapharm Pty Ltd, made a Statutory Declaration on 16 March 1987 stating that 51 per cent of the issued and fully-paid up share capital of the company is beneficially owned by either Australian companies or individuals who are citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.

No further enquiries on this matter are thought necessary at present. However, if the honourable senator has documentation suggesting that the extent of South African ownership of Protea Pharmaceuticals should be examined, or that the extent of South African ownership of Alphapharm Pty Ltd should be re-examined, I shall arrange for it to be considered by the IDC.

(2) The Government does not believe that it is necessary to legislate to compel overseas companies to provide proof of ownership before operating in Australia. In the administration of the Government's foreign investment policy, the establishment of new businesses in most sectors of the economy is only examinable if the total investment is to exceed $10 million. Experience has shown that foreign corporations readily provide details of ownership structures to the Government for the purposes of assessing proposals, wherever that is necessary. Moreover, the Government already has powers available to it under the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 to require corporations to provide information in circumstances where a substantial interest is being acquired by foreign interests in an Australian business or where the Treasurer has reason to believe that a person is capable of giving information relating to matters that are relevant to his powers under the Act. Formal use of these powers has rarely been contemplated and additional legislative requirements are not seen to be necessary.

(3) Information available is not sufficient to identify actual persons who own nursing homes. Enquiries made reveal that Mr Tabatznik is not known as an owner of a nursing home. To conduct a detailed search would require a search of Companies Office records in each State. This action would not appear to be warranted at this stage.
